componenttextpreview: Specialty has seen solid growth and that’s the one piece of our business that does have some private label involvement, a specialty products group. They’ve steadily increased their business both in the traditional items they’ve been in the past such
componenttext:
Specialty has seen solid growth and that’s the one piece of our business that does have some private label involvement, a specialty products group. They’ve steadily increased their business both in the traditional items they’ve been in the past such as gelatin but also some canned meat items and so that is contributing to results. The Diamond Crystal group has found ways to continue to grow their business even during the recession, they sold, in many cases to a different group of foodservice operators and then the meat side of our business traditionally focuses upon.
Then one other element that helped us this quarter was last year we had kind of a lag effect or negative effect from the Century Foods Operation as they had lost some significant business and they’ve done a nice job at replacing that business and getting back to more traditional margins for them. All three components are working well right now and our outlook for the second half would be for that to continue.

componenttext: On the Jennie-O business I don’t know that you said it, I’m scrambling here, did you say what your unit performance was there and do you expect, I know you’ve kept production there all proteins have essentially been cut. componenttextpreview: Total sales for Jennie-O were up 1%. The value added portion was up more than that and that’s the game plan. We have cut production over time, those production cuts are starting to lap the time when we cut them and so you won’t see the declines going
componenttext: Total sales for Jennie-O were up 1%. The value added portion was up more than that and that’s the game plan. We have cut production over time, those production cuts are starting to lap the time when we cut them and so you won’t see the declines going forward as much in terms of total tonnage. The focus continues to be driving more products into the value added area and we saw very solid sales from all three of the value added groups at Jennie-O.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: For the grocery items we are going to take a little bit of a wait and see approach. We certainly knew that this spike was coming but we’re still not clear on how long it’s going to last. When we take pricing on our branded items both within grocery an
componenttext: For the grocery items we are going to take a little bit of a wait and see approach. We certainly knew that this spike was coming but we’re still not clear on how long it’s going to last. When we take pricing on our branded items both within grocery and the meat products portfolio we want to have a reliable price out there in the marketplace that we can promote against. We’ve not made a call at this time yet as to whether that group needs to be looking at pricing on those specific items. As we move closer to the fall and we have a better look as to whether the hog market is going to be as Jody described and potentially receding back a bit or whether we’re at a new level then we’ll have to make that call.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I’m curious about the acquisition pipeline because I know last year you were saying that there were distressed assets on the block but that’s not really Hormel looks at. In thinking now there could be higher quality companies that sort of fit in your
componenttext: I’m curious about the acquisition pipeline because I know last year you were saying that there were distressed assets on the block but that’s not really Hormel looks at. In thinking now there could be higher quality companies that sort of fit in your profile that may be motivated by changes in tax laws to sell. So I’m wondering if the acquisition pipeline is more encouraging.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it’d be correct to say that the folks that we said were on the sidelines last year for valuation for economic reasons might be more encouraged now by the current environment. We’ve been probably just as active as ever in terms of exploring way
componenttext: I think it’d be correct to say that the folks that we said were on the sidelines last year for valuation for economic reasons might be more encouraged now by the current environment. We’ve been probably just as active as ever in terms of exploring ways to grow our business and utilize the cash that we know we have on hand and so we’re certainly actively exploring things but we don’t have anything to announce at this point. It’s the confluence of a willing seller, willing buyer, the right value and the right strategic fit that need to come together and we’ve had times in the past few years where we’ve had several of those kinds of things come together at once and then other times where we go a stretch without one.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Eric Larson - Soleil Securities
componenttext: Your next question comes from Eric Larson - Soleil Securities

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: My question relates to the protein markets right now, actually the hog markets have been benefiting quite nicely from a very strong ham export market. It seems like there’s selective strength on the export side. Then I think in your prepared comments
componenttext:
My question relates to the protein markets right now, actually the hog markets have been benefiting quite nicely from a very strong ham export market. It seems like there’s selective strength on the export side. Then I think in your prepared comments you talked about very strong exports in the dark turkey export market, dark parts market which if you get some good pricing and some good demand in that derivative market that’s really going to help your profitability for Jennie-O.
Can you give me a feel of what’s going on in these export markets and really the protein markets? Are these unusual events or are they sustainable and what’s driving those things?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: We certainly have seen that exports have been up year over year and I think the USDA most recent forecast is for a full calendar year to be up about 6%. Granted the ban from Russia was just lifted but they do have some restrictions, I believe on the amoun
componenttext: We certainly have seen that exports have been up year over year and I think the USDA most recent forecast is for a full calendar year to be up about 6%. Granted the ban from Russia was just lifted but they do have some restrictions, I believe on the amount of tonnage. Really the drivers have been our neighbors to the North and South, Mexico’s strength as well as Canada. How long we expect that to continue, boy depends on the economic conditions in those countries actually that are going to drive the exports as prices continue to stay firm. I would expect that we’ll see exports on the hog side or the pork side of things to be up in that 5% to 6% for the year.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: On the turkey side, the markets have been quite strong based on what we know right now our anticipation is that they would remain at that level. We’ve seen quite a recovery on the white meat side of the turkey business also in terms of the commodity mea
componenttext: On the turkey side, the markets have been quite strong based on what we know right now our anticipation is that they would remain at that level. We’ve seen quite a recovery on the white meat side of the turkey business also in terms of the commodity meat markets. Although that has less direct meaning to our results because we don’t sell a lot of surplus breast meat it is supportive of the overall market.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Robert Moskow - Credit Suisse
componenttext: Your next question comes from Robert Moskow - Credit Suisse

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you broader picture about the impact of higher hog prices on your two businesses. If all of these refrigerated meats and processed meats companies are getting hit by hog prices together wouldn’t it be fair to say that they would all rais
componenttext: I wanted to ask you broader picture about the impact of higher hog prices on your two businesses. If all of these refrigerated meats and processed meats companies are getting hit by hog prices together wouldn’t it be fair to say that they would all raise prices together because it’s the same impact across everybody?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: It certainly is the same impact across everybody but all businesses have to make independent business decisions. It may depend on the strength of their relationship with a given customer or the strength of their brand in a given marketplace. Clearly just
componenttext: It certainly is the same impact across everybody but all businesses have to make independent business decisions. It may depend on the strength of their relationship with a given customer or the strength of their brand in a given marketplace. Clearly just as we probably talked a year or two ago about realizing that in the long run the hog production deficit couldn’t last, the hog producers couldn’t last forever getting a negative return. Same would be true in terms of costs and pricing in the marketplace that if we attain a new level and it stays there for a while then in the long run prices are going to have to migrate up to that new level.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Stepping back, refrigerated products is that the easier part of the business to pass along the higher input costs because they tend to be, I don’t want to commoditized, but certainly it looks more like a refrigerated product rather than a packaged produ
componenttext: Stepping back, refrigerated products is that the easier part of the business to pass along the higher input costs because they tend to be, I don’t want to commoditized, but certainly it looks more like a refrigerated product rather than a packaged product.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: There’s a significant portion of the refrigerated food sales that that would definitely be correct for. The fresh pork items clearly trade on a market basis and ham and bacon sales traditionally in both the retail and food service trade move with market
componenttext: There’s a significant portion of the refrigerated food sales that that would definitely be correct for. The fresh pork items clearly trade on a market basis and ham and bacon sales traditionally in both the retail and food service trade move with markets and indeed we have taken pricing on those types of items to reflect what the current market conditions are. The items where you would not see that where we’re holding back and looking at them more as we do the grocery items would be the pepperoni and the refrigerated entrees and those types and Natural Choice those types of items.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Even Natural Choice it would be more challenging you think to take prices higher.
componenttext: Even Natural Choice it would be more challenging you think to take prices higher.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: We just look at it differently. I’m not saying it would be more challenging but we just look at that as a consumer packaged item that we don’t want to have it just fluctuating all the time based on underlying markets. Natural Choice frankly we sell ro
componenttext: We just look at it differently. I’m not saying it would be more challenging but we just look at that as a consumer packaged item that we don’t want to have it just fluctuating all the time based on underlying markets. Natural Choice frankly we sell roast beef, sliced ham and sliced turkey so you have all sorts of different inputs within the line. But you want to have a certain target price you’re looking for, for those lines, you have promoted prices you’re trying to attain and if we see in the long run that there’s a total difference in the cost that we have to deal with then we’ll have to address it accordingly in pricing but we just don’t do it on as quick a basis.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: If there is a negative thesis on Hormel it is that higher hog prices would impact your earnings growth going forward. What I’m trying to figure out is going into fiscal ’11 how big of a negative impact is it really? Is it enough to slow your ability t
componenttext: If there is a negative thesis on Hormel it is that higher hog prices would impact your earnings growth going forward. What I’m trying to figure out is going into fiscal ’11 how big of a negative impact is it really? Is it enough to slow your ability to hit your normal targets or is it just something that you can offset through other parts of your portfolio either because the portfolio is very balanced or because you think that pricing can eventually cover it.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: We have not completed any sort of budgeting cycle yet for 2011 but I can give you a general sense. We’ve talked before that one environment for our company that provides some short term challenges for certain units is when costs go up quickly. We certai
componenttext:
We have not completed any sort of budgeting cycle yet for 2011 but I can give you a general sense. We’ve talked before that one environment for our company that provides some short term challenges for certain units is when costs go up quickly. We certainly have seen that in the pork area. Baked into our second half number is the expectation that it’s going to be a more challenging environment for grocery products and refrigerated foods. We do think some of the other segments can offset that substantially but that is out there.
Our best outlook right now for 2011 would be along the lines of what you’re describing which is I would expect out team to react to the environmental change and we’re either going to have to address pricing if there is a new higher cost level that is going to stay in place or if some of those costs recede somewhat we should be in a position in 2011 to achieve our normal long term growth objectives.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: If we look at fiscal ’10 and how its playing out, the first half of the year you definitely over delivered on where you thought you would be and as we get to the second half of the year the comparisons are tougher, operating profit growth was very big i
componenttext: If we look at fiscal ’10 and how its playing out, the first half of the year you definitely over delivered on where you thought you would be and as we get to the second half of the year the comparisons are tougher, operating profit growth was very big in the second half of fiscal ’09 so it will be a comparison issue and maybe a little bit of a challenging environment because of the higher hog prices, it’s kind of like a tail of two hats for fiscal ’10.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that’s fair but again we try to run the business on the basis of the full year and that was part of why we moved to annualized guidance. By moving up our guidance range now, it’s the second time we’ve done it this year, the mid point of that
componenttext: I think that’s fair but again we try to run the business on the basis of the full year and that was part of why we moved to annualized guidance. By moving up our guidance range now, it’s the second time we’ve done it this year, the mid point of that range would be a solid 10% increase on an earnings per share basis over last year’s results and a better increase than that on an operating profit basis because you want to wash out the rabbi trust effect. We’re going to look at the year and see if we can deliver the second half the way we’ve described it as being a very successful year and one we can build on going forward.

componenttext: You have accumulated a nice amount of cash on your balance sheet, just wondering if you could review your priority use of cash again.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I’m afraid they haven’t changed since last time but certainly as Jeff indicated before, we continue to look at opportunities to invest strategically either internally. Our CapEx spending has been lower and I guided the full year a little bit lower bec
componenttext: I’m afraid they haven’t changed since last time but certainly as Jeff indicated before, we continue to look at opportunities to invest strategically either internally. Our CapEx spending has been lower and I guided the full year a little bit lower because while we’ve got great projects in the pipeline it seems to be that we’re taking a little longer than I originally anticipated in getting some of those things done and equipment ordered and what not. CapEx should be coming back online and getting back to more normalized levels in the back half of the year. We look at acquisitions, investing in our own business; certainly we’re committed to our dividends to our shareholders and share repurchase as well. Those seem to be the key.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Mike Hamilton - RBC Dain Rauscher
componenttext: Your next question comes from Mike Hamilton - RBC Dain Rauscher

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: It’s been a while since I’ve heard you discuss the dynamics of your hog contracts. I’m wondering, given the volatility of what we’ve been through kind of from 30,000 feet if you could assess what you’ve accomplished, what you’re seeing out the
componenttext: It’s been a while since I’ve heard you discuss the dynamics of your hog contracts. I’m wondering, given the volatility of what we’ve been through kind of from 30,000 feet if you could assess what you’ve accomplished, what you’re seeing out there, if you think you’re taking market share, if this environment has given you an opportunity to continue to upgrade the quality of your producers in terms of their financial strength and capabilities. The picture as you see it of the progress you’ve made there.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Our hog contracts generally are based on markets so it’s usually a spread to the Western corn belts since that’s where most of our hogs are sourced. We really do follow the market. We have been fortunate that the producers we’ve aligned ourselves wi
componenttext:
Our hog contracts generally are based on markets so it’s usually a spread to the Western corn belts since that’s where most of our hogs are sourced. We really do follow the market. We have been fortunate that the producers we’ve aligned ourselves with have had a lot of financial strength. We have some of the smaller operators have fallen on the wayside when they’ve got in over their heads and were losing money but generally our producers have been stronger. 
We continue to work with other producers that maybe are unhappy with their current packer that they’re dealing with and have some opportunities there. We feel very comfortable about the supply of hogs for the future for Hormel and these are generally long term contracts, five to 10 years.

componenttext: The last time we had an authorization I think it was in 2003 that it was implemented so obviously we’ve been given the long term for it. headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: As I’d indicated in an answer to Ann earlier was we have projects in the pipeline for CapEx, it’s not for lack of wanting to do things they just seem to be taking longer than I originally anticipated in my guidance. I did pull it down for the full yea
componenttext: As I’d indicated in an answer to Ann earlier was we have projects in the pipeline for CapEx, it’s not for lack of wanting to do things they just seem to be taking longer than I originally anticipated in my guidance. I did pull it down for the full year. I think its being conservative, we might go over that but I was trying to give you a real picture of where I felt our CapEx spending would be. The new plant basically up and going, obviously we’re adding some additional production capabilities into there, that should get in this year. I know Jennie-O has some specific projects that they’re working on but they don’t seem to be happening as fast as I thought they would.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: One comment and I wanted to get your reaction. Most of your protein competitors who are publicly traded ones who are more on the non-value added side had said that we are tight protein right now especially beef and pork and chicken may be changing. In tha
componenttext: One comment and I wanted to get your reaction. Most of your protein competitors who are publicly traded ones who are more on the non-value added side had said that we are tight protein right now especially beef and pork and chicken may be changing. In that environment some of the publicly traded ones have actually increased their normalized margin ranges for pork margins etc. Do you agree that we are “tight protein” and if that’s the case doesn’t that bode well for pricing in grocery products as you look at it over the next six months or so?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Actually I would agree that protein certainly is significantly tighter than it was a year ago or two years ago. The pricing equation has other elements to it. You have to look at other feature alternatives that the retailers have, we certainly have to be
componenttext: Actually I would agree that protein certainly is significantly tighter than it was a year ago or two years ago. The pricing equation has other elements to it. You have to look at other feature alternatives that the retailers have, we certainly have to be mindful of a consumer that in many cases is having constrained budget and is looking for as good a value as possible on items. We have to balance what the needs would be in terms of pricing to cover down our costs and what the market will bear in terms of what our consumers are looking to pay.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Hormel Foods Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call on today, the 19th of May 2010. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to hand the conference over to your host, Mr. Kevin Jones. Pl
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Hormel Foods Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call on today, the 19th of May 2010. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to hand the conference over to your host, Mr. Kevin Jones. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Donnie. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to the Hormel Foods Conference Call for the Second Quarter of Fiscal 2010. We released our results this morning before the market opened around 6:30 a.m. Central Time. If you did not receive a copy of the
componenttext:
Thank you, Donnie. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to the Hormel Foods Conference Call for the Second Quarter of Fiscal 2010. We released our results this morning before the market opened around 6:30 a.m. Central Time. If you did not receive a copy of the release, you can find it on our website at www.hormelfoods.com under the Investor section.
On our call today is Jeff Ettinger, Chairman of the Board, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jody Feragen, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Because Jeff and I are in New York, and Jody is in Austin, you may experience a bit of a delay in some of our responses to your questions as we sort out who should respond to a particular question. We appreciate your patience in that regard. 
Jeff will provide a review of the operating results for the quarter, then Jody will provide detailed financial results for the quarter. The line will be then open for questions following Jody's remarks.  An audio replay of this call will be available beginning at 10:30 a.m. Central Time today, May 19, 2010. The dial-in number is (800)406-7325 and the access code is 4286994. It will also be posted to our website and archived for one year. 
Before we get started with the results of the quarter, I need to reference the Safe Harbor statement. Some of the comments made today will be forward-looking and are made under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from those expressed in or implied by the statements we will be making. Among the factors that may affect the operating results of the company are fluctuations in the cost and availability of raw materials and market conditions for finished products.
Please refer to Pages 27 through 33 in the company's form 10-Q for the quarter ended January 24, 2010, which was filed with the SEC on March 5, 2010, for more details. It can be accessed on our website. Now I'll turn the call over to Jeff.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin. It's nice to be here in New York this morning and have the opportunity to talk about another fine quarter of results. We are pleased to report strong earnings and sales for the second quarter. Our Q2 earnings of $0.67 per share, excludin
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin. It's nice to be here in New York this morning and have the opportunity to talk about another fine quarter of results. We are pleased to report strong earnings and sales for the second quarter. Our Q2 earnings of $0.67 per share, excluding the one-time charges of $0.10 per share associated with the plant closing and the health care laws, represent a 14% increase over our results of the year ago. Total dollar sales were also up 7% over a year ago. This quarter once again demonstrates the benefit of our balanced business model, as the strong performance of our Jennie-O Turkey Store and Specialty Foods segments more than made up for the results of our Grocery Product and all other segments. 
I will now take you through each segment. Our Grocery Products segment reported a $1 sales increase of 6% and a segment operating profit decrease of 2%, the latter after adjusting for the one-time charges associated with our golf [ph] VALLEY FRESH plant closing. Net of the new item sales of Mexican products under the MegaMex Foods venture and of the discontinued CARAPELLI Olive Oil sales, revenues for Grocery Products would have been flat for the quarter.
Stronger sales of our Mexican products and our Hormel Chili and Hormel Mary Kitchen hash products were not able to completely offset the pressure on margins in our SPAM family of products and our Hormel Bacon Bits items, prompted by higher raw material costs. The increased sales of Hormel Chili and Hormel Mary Kitchen hash resulted from increased distribution and from our new Hormel brand advertising campaign. The campaign is designed to leverage our leading brand strength in numerous categories to promote cross purchase intent. We are pleased with the success of our MegaMex Foods venture so far, as sales of over $120 million through the first half are on pace to easily exceed the base level sales of $200 million on an annualized basis. 
Our Refrigerated Foods segment reported operating profit of 7%, aided by stronger cutout margins compared to a year ago. Sales were also up 7% for Refrigerated Foods. We enjoyed particularly strong sales of Hormel Party Trays and Hormel pepperoni, helped in part by new products and in part by our Hormel brand advertising campaign and in part by the great efforts of our sales organization in generating meaningful in-store promotions.
We are pleased with the progress in the integration of our recent Country Crock Side Dish business. Our team has done a good job stabilizing this business during the quarter. We can now provide complete meal solutions to consumers in the Refrigerated section of the store, complementing our Hormel refrigerated entrées and Lloyd's Barbecue products. We have begun to see signs of improvement in the Foodservice trades. Sales of our Natural Choice deli meats, Austin Blues barbecue products and Café H ethnic products all grew during the quarter.
Segment operating profit at our Jennie-O Turkey Store segment increased by a noteworthy 93%, with sales up 1%. Jennie-O's results came from improved efficiencies throughout the entire business. Export sales of dark turkey meat have given us an added boost as thigh meat pricing has remained very strong. Sales increased for Jennie-O in all three value-added areas, retail, deli and Foodservice, led by retail tray pack fresh turkey and rotisserie deli products. We continue to generate excellent exposure for the Jennie-O Turkey Store brand through our sponsorship of the Biggest Loser reality TV show. 
Our Specialty Foods segment again posted improved segment operating profit and sales, up 39% and 13% respectively, with contributions by all three subunits of Specialty Foods. The leading drivers of these improved results were sports nutrition products, private-label canned meat products and sugar substitutes.
In our All Other International segment, segment operating profit declined 18%, while sales increased by 7%. We did generate excellent sales of our SPAM family of products, but this was not sufficient to offset the reduced returns we experienced related to lower fresh pork exports. In our February call, we mentioned that higher hog costs were on their way. These increased costs did indeed arrive and at a higher level than originally anticipated. We expect this trend to continue as we get into warmer weather. 
On the other hand, commodity turkey prices have firmed up as a result of industry production cuts and grain prices appear to be on a fairly stable position. Taking these considerations into account and in light of our strong results in Q2, we are again raising our full year guidance range from $2.68 to $2.78 per share to $2.75 to $2.85 per share, excluding the one-time charges of $0.10 per share associated with the plant closing and health care laws. 
At this time, I will turn the call over to Jody Feragen in Austin to discuss the financial information relating to the second quarter.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeff. Good morning, everyone. As we announced in our earnings release issued this morning, our second quarter results were impacted by the one-time charges related to the closure of our plant in Turlock, California and tax charges primarily rel
componenttext:
Thank you, Jeff. Good morning, everyone. As we announced in our earnings release issued this morning, our second quarter results were impacted by the one-time charges related to the closure of our plant in Turlock, California and tax charges primarily related to the newly enacted health care laws. These one-time charges resulted in an adjustment to diluted net earnings of approximately $0.10 per share for the second quarter. A table reconciling our adjusted earning calculations to earnings calculated under Generally Accepted Accounting Principles was included in our earnings release as well.
For the second quarter of 2010, adjusted net earnings totaled $91.3 million or $0.67 per share compared to $80.4 million or $0.59 per share a year ago. Adjusted net earnings for the first half of fiscal 2010 totaled $202.5 million or $1.50 per share compared to $161.8 million or $1.20 per share a year ago. On a GAAP basis, net earnings for the second quarter of 2010 totaled $77.9 million or $0.57 per share. GAAP net earnings for the first half of 2010 were $189.1 million or $1.40 per share.
Dollar sales for the second quarter totaled $1.7 billion compared to $1.6 billion last year, a 7% increase. For the first half of the fiscal year, dollar sales increased 4% to $3.4 billion. Volume for the second quarter was 1.1 billion pounds, up 2% from fiscal 2009. Year-to-date, volume was $2.3 billion, also up 2% from fiscal 2009. 
Selling, general and administrative expenses in the second quarter were 8.6% of sales compared to 8.8% last year. Year-to-date, selling, general and administrative expenses were 8.5% compared to 8.6% last year. We expect selling, general and administrative expenses to be approximately 8.8% of sales for the remainder of the year. Advertising expenses were 1.5% of sales for the quarter compared to 1.6% in 2009. Year-to-date, advertising expenses are 1.5% of sales, even with last year. We saw an absolute dollar increase in advertising expense in the second quarter and expect that advertising dollars will exceed 2009 expenditures on a full year basis.
Interest in investment income was $1.4 million for the second quarter compared to $8.6 million in fiscal 2009. In the second quarter of fiscal 2009, we recorded a $3.6 million gain on the dissolution of the CARAPELLI joint venture. In addition, we experienced higher returns on our rabbi trust investments in 2009. We expect difficult comparisons in the back half of the year due to the strong performance of our rabbi trust investments in 2009.
Interest expense for the quarter was $6.6 million compared to $6.9 million last year. Year-to-date, interest expense is $13.1 million compared to $14.4 million last year. We expect interest expense to be approximately $27 million to $28 million for fiscal 2010. Our effective tax rate in the second quarter was 40.7% versus 35.3% in fiscal 2009. The increase in 2010 was driven by the one-time impact of recently enacted Health Care legislation and the reduction in the value of our deferred tax asset due to the change in the tax treatment of Medicare Part D reimbursements. Year-to-date, effective tax rate is 36.8% compared to 34.9% last year. For fiscal 2010, we expect the effective tax rate to be between 36% and 37%.
Basic weighted average number of shares outstanding for the second quarter was 134 million. The diluted weighted average number of shares outstanding for the second quarter was 136 million shares. We repurchased 330,000 shares of common stock during the second quarter and have 367,000 shares remaining to be repurchased from the 10 million share authorization in place. 
Total debt at the end of the quarter was $350 million. Depreciation and amortization for the quarter was $31 million, even with last year. For the first half of the year, depreciation and amortization was $61 million compared to $62 million last year. We expect depreciation and amortization to be approximately $125 million to $127 million in fiscal 2010.
Capital expenditures for the quarter totaled $22 million compared to $20 million last year. For the first six months of the year, capital expenditures totaled $40 million compared to $46 million last year. For fiscal 2010, we expect capital expenditures to be approximately $105 million to $115 million. At this time, I will turn the call over to the operator for the question-and-answer portion of the call. Operator?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And the first question comes from Farha Aslam. [Stephens Inc.]
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And the first question comes from Farha Aslam. [Stephens Inc.]

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: My question relates to hog prices and the impact on refrigerated foods and grocery products. This quarter you benefited from a really good cutout. Do you think that cutout continues to help results going in to the third quarter? Or do you think the higher
componenttext: My question relates to hog prices and the impact on refrigerated foods and grocery products. This quarter you benefited from a really good cutout. Do you think that cutout continues to help results going in to the third quarter? Or do you think the higher hog prices are going to come pass the cutout and therefore, pressure margins in that business?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: If it's okay, I'll go ahead and have Jody start with that question and if you need any additional follow-ups, I'd be happy to provide it.
componenttext: If it's okay, I'll go ahead and have Jody start with that question and if you need any additional follow-ups, I'd be happy to provide it.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: We certainly have seen hog costs that are much higher than in 2009. And as we expected, they happened a little sooner for us this year. I don't expect the trend to keep escalating in hog prices. I expect they'll stay high. The cutout, we've seen a nice sp
componenttext: We certainly have seen hog costs that are much higher than in 2009. And as we expected, they happened a little sooner for us this year. I don't expect the trend to keep escalating in hog prices. I expect they'll stay high. The cutout, we've seen a nice spread there as you've commented. The cutout really is going to depend on what the demand side of the equation. Exports have been strong, if those continue, there is a possibility for the cutout to move up as well, but then also you have the impact of the rising prices and what that does to consumer demand. So I don't see the cutout as clearly as I do on the hog price side.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And then my follow-up is on Turkey. You had an extraordinary margin in the quarter. It's above your corporate target of 8% to 10%. Do you anticipate Turkey to remain above that corporate target for the rest of the year?
componenttext: And then my follow-up is on Turkey. You had an extraordinary margin in the quarter. It's above your corporate target of 8% to 10%. Do you anticipate Turkey to remain above that corporate target for the rest of the year?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Farha, quarter-to-quarter on the Turkey business does vary somewhat. But if you compare it to, I mean, the proper quarter comparison, we do think conditions are fairly favorable right now for the Jennie-O Turkey Store group and that they're attainin
componenttext: Well, Farha, quarter-to-quarter on the Turkey business does vary somewhat. But if you compare it to, I mean, the proper quarter comparison, we do think conditions are fairly favorable right now for the Jennie-O Turkey Store group and that they're attaining a lot of efficiencies in their operations. So I do think that will continue to track somewhat above the typical quarter in each case.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Jonathan Feeney. [Janney Montgomery Scott]
componenttext: And the next question comes from Jonathan Feeney. [Janney Montgomery Scott]

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: If I were to think about the Refrigerated Foods business as splitted in two parts, the profits you enjoy from commodity sort of just slaughtering and business you've de-emphasized over the past 10 years and the sort of more value-added component taking th
componenttext: If I were to think about the Refrigerated Foods business as splitted in two parts, the profits you enjoy from commodity sort of just slaughtering and business you've de-emphasized over the past 10 years and the sort of more value-added component taking those meats from, I know you get them internally, but from wherever you would happen to get them and selling with some value-added form. Can you give me a sense of what the two components would have looked like this quarter if I were to split it in that way?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the commodity side that you're describing would have benefited from more favorable cutout margins during the quarter. The value-added story has been a bit more mixed. We still have a number of items within the value-added portfolios of both
componenttext: Well, I think the commodity side that you're describing would have benefited from more favorable cutout margins during the quarter. The value-added story has been a bit more mixed. We still have a number of items within the value-added portfolios of both Meat Products and Foodservice that are doing very well in the current environment. And then we have others that are a little bit softer based on the steep ramp up in costs that we've been seeing.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: But could you give me a sense what those ballpark, what those components would be between commodity and value add and what that usually is?
componenttext: But could you give me a sense what those ballpark, what those components would be between commodity and value add and what that usually is?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't have a profit breakdown for you. And I think we have talked in the past that approximately 75% of our sales go out in a form that we consider to be the value-added products.
componenttext: I don't have a profit breakdown for you. And I think we have talked in the past that approximately 75% of our sales go out in a form that we consider to be the value-added products.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: But I mean, am I right? I guess, let me just think about -- is the historical range anywhere from -- I always thought it was anywhere between 50%, 60% of the total profits to 120% of the total profits of that business would be value added. Would that be a
componenttext: But I mean, am I right? I guess, let me just think about -- is the historical range anywhere from -- I always thought it was anywhere between 50%, 60% of the total profits to 120% of the total profits of that business would be value added. Would that be a right range?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, clearly, we described what the percentage of sales was value added and we do expect that the value-added items should attain a better profit margin and a more reliable profit margin than the commodity side.
componenttext: Well, I mean, clearly, we described what the percentage of sales was value added and we do expect that the value-added items should attain a better profit margin and a more reliable profit margin than the commodity side.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Akshay Jagdale. [KeyBanc Capital Markets Inc.]
componenttext: And the next question comes from Akshay Jagdale. [KeyBanc Capital Markets Inc.]

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Just one question on Grocery Products and if I can, another one on Turkey. In Grocery Products, it seems like the margins sequentially came down. Looks like that's the piece of your business that got most impacted by higher costs. Can you talk about how m
componenttext: Just one question on Grocery Products and if I can, another one on Turkey. In Grocery Products, it seems like the margins sequentially came down. Looks like that's the piece of your business that got most impacted by higher costs. Can you talk about how much of that is a timing issue? And also, I mean, the volumes were really strong again. And I may have missed your commentary on that, so if you could comment on those two things.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: For Grocery Products?
componenttext: For Grocery Products?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Akshay, I do think that for second quarter results, you saw a more pronounced impact on the cost increase on their sides of the business. We did feel the same impact in certain elements on the Refrigerated Foods portfolio, but they have the offset of the
componenttext: Akshay, I do think that for second quarter results, you saw a more pronounced impact on the cost increase on their sides of the business. We did feel the same impact in certain elements on the Refrigerated Foods portfolio, but they have the offset of the hog cutouts to dissipate that somewhat. Now items that are pork-based items, particularly our SPAM luncheon meat or Hormel Bacon Bits, did see early steep increases in the raw material costs during the quarter and that have compressed the margins then to a lower level than what we have been generating in the prior quarter and even the prior same quarter last year. In terms of sales, Grocery Products overall, they generate positive sales for the quarter. As I mentioned, if you sort out the discontinued business, the CARAPELLI, and you put aside the new franchises that we joined to the company through the MegaMex venture, the net effect of those two would be to flatten out GP sales, so it was kind of a mixed bag again within their portfolio. Chili did well, hash did well, the Mexican products did well. Compleats was sort of back to even, which was just trending the direction we needed to trend. But we did see softer sales of some of the other canned items such as SPAM and Dinty Moore this quarter and the chunk meat items also were a little bit off.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And just one follow-up if I can on Turkey. I know Farha asked something to this extent. But if I look at the seasonality in your business, obviously 4Q and I believe 1Q for your fiscal year are the best seasonal quarters for Turkey and the highest margin
componenttext: And just one follow-up if I can on Turkey. I know Farha asked something to this extent. But if I look at the seasonality in your business, obviously 4Q and I believe 1Q for your fiscal year are the best seasonal quarters for Turkey and the highest margin at quarterly basis in those quarters is around 13.5%. It seems as though turkey, much like chicken, is set up pretty well right now, supply-demand wise, and you have some momentum on the profit margins going in. I mean, do you see this being -- 4Q could be a record profit year for Turkey? I mean, the profits should trend up, right?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Without giving you a specific number in terms of net margins for the division, that clearly would be our position that we talked about our balanced model, that as we feel a little bit of pressure in the Grocery and Refrigerated segments for their val
componenttext: Yes. Without giving you a specific number in terms of net margins for the division, that clearly would be our position that we talked about our balanced model, that as we feel a little bit of pressure in the Grocery and Refrigerated segments for their value-added items with the spike in pork costs, we do feel we have an offset in place with more favorable conditions and solid results for Jennie-O. So it would be correct that we should be able to trend upward from what we delivered this quarter on a quarterly basis.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Diane Geissler. [Calyon Securities]
componenttext: And the next question comes from Diane Geissler. [Calyon Securities]

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Jody, can you tell me what was your average live hog price in the quarter? And then as we look to your increased guidance, what are you booking in for hog prices for the back half of the year?
componenttext: Jody, can you tell me what was your average live hog price in the quarter? And then as we look to your increased guidance, what are you booking in for hog prices for the back half of the year?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Our average hog cost this year was about $10, alive, hundredweight more than 2009.
componenttext: Our average hog cost this year was about $10, alive, hundredweight more than 2009.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Is that a first half or a second quarter number?
componenttext: Is that a first half or a second quarter number?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: That's a second quarter number. And yes, about $10 over what we paid in the second quarter of 2009. I actually think that we're going to see hog prices kind of stay at this elevated level, but perhaps not trend up too much higher, so I haven't put a lot o
componenttext: That's a second quarter number. And yes, about $10 over what we paid in the second quarter of 2009. I actually think that we're going to see hog prices kind of stay at this elevated level, but perhaps not trend up too much higher, so I haven't put a lot of increase in the back half of the year. I do think that after our fiscal year, we'll probably see them come down quite a bit. I have a feeling that these are attractive prices for producers and that some of those empty sow stalls will now start filling up.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And then I guess for Jeff, I know you talked a little bit about seeing your recovery in Foodservice. I guess, we could look at your portfolio and say you probably had some brands that did very well with the value-conscious consumer. Can you just talk abou
componenttext: And then I guess for Jeff, I know you talked a little bit about seeing your recovery in Foodservice. I guess, we could look at your portfolio and say you probably had some brands that did very well with the value-conscious consumer. Can you just talk about what you expect over the next six months? If we do see a shift out of retail into Foodservice, what that means for your portfolio, and I guess, even within the Grocery Products. I would guess Compleats would do a little bit better, but SPAM wouldn't be a little bit weaker, but I'd like to hear what your nearby forecast is, so say, with the next six months for your product portfolio?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: We're certainly seeing more favorable signs in the Foodservice environment. I mean, if you look at kind of total sales for Hormel Foodservice, for example, they were flat for the quarter. On the branded or more highly value-added items, we saw some gains.
componenttext: We're certainly seeing more favorable signs in the Foodservice environment. I mean, if you look at kind of total sales for Hormel Foodservice, for example, they were flat for the quarter. On the branded or more highly value-added items, we saw some gains. And we had more territories up than we're down, and that was an encouraging sign versus prior years. We would expect that trend to gradually accelerate. I guess, we don't feel that we're not hearing from the Foodservice market place that the clouds have all parted and everything is excellent now. But if we do experience a shift where people start going out a little bit more often and businesses start attending a few more conferences, et cetera, we're certainly well positioned to take advantage of that. We have Foodservice elements in four of our five operating segments, and they're all poised with good sales organizations and with good products hopefully to deliver against that audience. Within the grocery environment, not talking just grocery products, but grocery stores, our impression has been that the recession has had mixed results. I mean, we clearly saw some benefit to the traditional canned franchises for a time there where almost all of those items were up. This quarter was more mixed in that regard with Chili and hash up and Dinty Moore and SPAM down. But we also did lose some momentum in our convenience items, both Compleats and our refrigerated entrées during last year. And so as consumers gain more confidence and economy starts looking better, we do expect those franchises to improve.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Tim Ramey. [D.A. Davidson & Co.]
componenttext: And the next question comes from Tim Ramey. [D.A. Davidson & Co.]

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, the improvement in Specialty was impressive. And I'm wondering if there's any new product activity or new activity for new co-pac [contract packing] activity for customers there or if that's just kind of a steady-state improvement?
componenttext: Jeff, the improvement in Specialty was impressive. And I'm wondering if there's any new product activity or new activity for new co-pac [contract packing] activity for customers there or if that's just kind of a steady-state improvement?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Specialty has seen solid growth and that's the one piece of our business that does have some private-label involvement, Specialty Products group. And they steadily increased their business both in the traditional items they've been in the past such
componenttext: Well, Specialty has seen solid growth and that's the one piece of our business that does have some private-label involvement, Specialty Products group. And they steadily increased their business both in the traditional items they've been in the past such as gelatin but also some canned meat items, and so that is contributing to results. The Diamond Crystal group has found ways to continue to grow their business even during the recession. They sell in many cases to a different group of Foodservice operators than the meat side of our business to traditionally focuses upon. And then one other element that helped us this quarter was last year we had kind of a lag effect or a negative effect from the Century Foods operation as they had lost some significant business, and they've done a nice job of replacing that business and getting back to more traditional margins for them. So all three components are working well right now, and our outlook for the second half would be for that to continue.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And just a quick follow-up on the Jennie-O business. I don't know that you said it, I'm scrambling here. Did you say what you're unit performance was there? And do you expect, I mean, I know you've cut production there, all proteins have essentially been
componenttext: And just a quick follow-up on the Jennie-O business. I don't know that you said it, I'm scrambling here. Did you say what you're unit performance was there? And do you expect, I mean, I know you've cut production there, all proteins have essentially been cut, but what should we expect for the rest of the year on sort of your unit performance there?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I want to make sure when you say unit performance, what you're...
componenttext: I want to make sure when you say unit performance, what you're...

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Tonnage, I guess.
componenttext: Tonnage, I guess.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, total sales for Jennie-O were up 1%. The value-added portion was up more than that, and that's the game plan. I mean, we have cut production over time. Those production cuts are starting to lap the time when we cut them, and so you won't see
componenttext: Yes, I mean, total sales for Jennie-O were up 1%. The value-added portion was up more than that, and that's the game plan. I mean, we have cut production over time. Those production cuts are starting to lap the time when we cut them, and so you won't see the declines going forward as much in terms of total tonnage. But the focus continues to be driving more products into the value-added area, and we saw really kind of very solid sales from all three of the value-added groups at Jennie-O.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Christina McGlone. [Deutsche Bank]
componenttext: And the next question comes from Christina McGlone. [Deutsche Bank]

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, you talked about flat sales in Grocery without the acquisitions and dispositions. What would volumes have been, just because I'm curious what the price mix is and the core price mix in that division?
componenttext: Jeff, you talked about flat sales in Grocery without the acquisitions and dispositions. What would volumes have been, just because I'm curious what the price mix is and the core price mix in that division?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: My recollection is that it'd be fairly similar without the, again, excluding those items. If any of the folks in Austin have a different number, please go ahead and chime in.
componenttext: My recollection is that it'd be fairly similar without the, again, excluding those items. If any of the folks in Austin have a different number, please go ahead and chime in.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, volume was down just a little bit more than flat. Volume was a little bit more negative. But you get into all the mix issue, so that's kind of a difficult one.
componenttext: Jeff, volume was down just a little bit more than flat. Volume was a little bit more negative. But you get into all the mix issue, so that's kind of a difficult one.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: So I guess the question is, given the raw material increase, what do you think the outlook is for pricing in Grocery? And what do you think the retail and consumer response will be?
componenttext: So I guess the question is, given the raw material increase, what do you think the outlook is for pricing in Grocery? And what do you think the retail and consumer response will be?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, for the grocery items, we are going to take a little bit of a wait-and-see approach. I mean, we certainly knew that this spike was coming, but we're still not clear on how long it's going to last. When we take pricing on our branded items, both with
componenttext: Well, for the grocery items, we are going to take a little bit of a wait-and-see approach. I mean, we certainly knew that this spike was coming, but we're still not clear on how long it's going to last. When we take pricing on our branded items, both within Grocery and the Meat Products portfolio, we want to have a reliable price out there in the marketplace that then we can promote against. And so we've not made a call at this time yet as to whether that group needs to be looking at pricing on those specific items. As we move closer to the fall and we have a better look as to whether the hog market's going to be, as Jody described, and potentially receding back a bit or whether we're at a new level, then we'll have to make that call.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And Jeff, I'm curious about the acquisition pipeline. Because I know last year, you were saying that there were distressed assets on the block, but that's not really what Hormel looks at. But I'm thinking now there could be higher quality companies that s
componenttext: And Jeff, I'm curious about the acquisition pipeline. Because I know last year, you were saying that there were distressed assets on the block, but that's not really what Hormel looks at. But I'm thinking now there could be higher quality companies that sort of fit in your profile that may be motivated by changes in tax loss to sell. So I'm wondering if the acquisition pipeline is more encouraging.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it'd be correct to say that the folks that we say we're on the sidelines last year for evaluation or economic reasons might be more encouraged now by the current environment. We've been quite just as active as ever in terms of exploring ways to gr
componenttext: I think it'd be correct to say that the folks that we say we're on the sidelines last year for evaluation or economic reasons might be more encouraged now by the current environment. We've been quite just as active as ever in terms of exploring ways to grow our business and utilize the cash that we know we have on hand. And so we're certainly actively exploring things, but we don't have anything to announce at this point. And it's a confluence of a seller willing buyer, the right value and the right strategic fit that need to come together. And we've had times in the past few years where we've had several of those kind of things come together at once and on other times, where we go a stretch without one.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Eric Larson. [Soleil Securities Group]
componenttext: And the next question comes from Eric Larson. [Soleil Securities Group]

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: My question relates to the protein markets right now. Actually, the hog markets have been benefiting quite nicely from a very strong ham export market. It seems like there's selective strength on the export side. And then I think in your prepared comments
componenttext: My question relates to the protein markets right now. Actually, the hog markets have been benefiting quite nicely from a very strong ham export market. It seems like there's selective strength on the export side. And then I think in your prepared comments, Jeff, you talked about very strong exports in the dark turkey export market, dark parts market, which if you get some good pricing and some good demand in that derivative market, that's really going to help your profitability for Jennie-O. So can you give me a feel of what's going on in these export markets? And really, the protein markets -- are these unusual events? Or are these sustainable? And what's driving those things?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, why don't I let I Jody start with it and talk about the hog side of the equation, and I think I could fill in on the turkey markets.
componenttext: Well, why don't I let I Jody start with it and talk about the hog side of the equation, and I think I could fill in on the turkey markets.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we certainly have seen that exports have been up year-over-year. And I think the USDA's most recent forecasts is for a full calendar year to be up about 6%, granted the ban from Russia was just lifted but they do have some restrictions, I believe, on
componenttext: Yes, we certainly have seen that exports have been up year-over-year. And I think the USDA's most recent forecasts is for a full calendar year to be up about 6%, granted the ban from Russia was just lifted but they do have some restrictions, I believe, on the amount of tonnage. Really, the drivers have been our neighbors to the north and south, Mexico's strength as well as Canada. How long we expect that to continue, boy, depends on the economic conditions in those countries actually that are going to drive the export as prices continue to stay firm. So I would expect that we will see exports on the hog side or the meat side of pork side of things to be up in that 5% to 6% for the year.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Eric, on the turkey side, I mean, the markets have been quite strong based on what we know right now. Our anticipation is that they would remain at that level. We've seen quite a recovery on the white meat side of the Turkey business also in terms of the
componenttext: Eric, on the turkey side, I mean, the markets have been quite strong based on what we know right now. Our anticipation is that they would remain at that level. We've seen quite a recovery on the white meat side of the Turkey business also in terms of the commodity meat markets. And although that has less direct meaning to our result, because we don't sell a lot of surplus breast meat, it is supportive of the overall market.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Robert Moskow. [Crédit Suisse]
componenttext: And the next question comes from Robert Moskow. [Crédit Suisse]

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you about just a broader picture about the impact of higher hog prices on your two businesses. If all of these refrigerated meats and processed meats companies are getting hit by hog prices together, wouldn't it be fair to say that they wo
componenttext: I wanted to ask you about just a broader picture about the impact of higher hog prices on your two businesses. If all of these refrigerated meats and processed meats companies are getting hit by hog prices together, wouldn't it be fair to say that they would all raise prices together because it's the same impact across everybody?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it's certainly is the same impact across everybody, but all businesses have to make independent business decisions. It may dependent on the strength of their relationship with a given customer or the strength of their brand in a given market place.
componenttext: Well, it's certainly is the same impact across everybody, but all businesses have to make independent business decisions. It may dependent on the strength of their relationship with a given customer or the strength of their brand in a given market place. But clearly, just as we priced hog a year or two ago about realizing that in the long run, the hog production deficit couldn't last, that the hog producers couldn't last forever getting a negative return. Same would be true in terms of cost and pricing in the marketplace, that if we attain a new level and it stays there for a while, then in the long run, prices are going to have to migrate up to that new level.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Do you think, stepping back, refrigerated products, is that kind of the easier part of the business to pass along the higher input cost because they tend to be, I don't want to say commoditized, but certainly, it looks more like a refrigerated product rat
componenttext: Do you think, stepping back, refrigerated products, is that kind of the easier part of the business to pass along the higher input cost because they tend to be, I don't want to say commoditized, but certainly, it looks more like a refrigerated product rather than a packaged product?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Robert, there's a significant portion of the refrigerated food sales that, that would definitely be correct for. The fresh pork items clearly trade on a market basis and ham and bacon sales traditionally in both the retail and Foodservice trade move with
componenttext: Robert, there's a significant portion of the refrigerated food sales that, that would definitely be correct for. The fresh pork items clearly trade on a market basis and ham and bacon sales traditionally in both the retail and Foodservice trade move with markets and indeed, we have taken pricing on those types of items to reflect what the current market conditions are. The items where you would not see that, where we're holding back and looking at them more as we do the grocery items would be the pepperonis and the refrigerated entrées and those types and then Natural Choice, those types of items.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: So even Natural Choice, it would be more challenging, you think, to take prices higher?
componenttext: So even Natural Choice, it would be more challenging, you think, to take prices higher?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we just look at it differently. I'm not saying it would be more challenging, but we just look at that as a consumer packaged item that we don't want to have it just fluctuating all the time based on underlying markets. I mean, Natural Choice, we sell
componenttext: Yes, we just look at it differently. I'm not saying it would be more challenging, but we just look at that as a consumer packaged item that we don't want to have it just fluctuating all the time based on underlying markets. I mean, Natural Choice, we sell roast beef, sliced ham and sliced turkey, so you have all sorts of different inputs within the line. But you want to have a certain target price you're looking for, for those lines. You have promoted prices you're trying to attain. And if we see in the long run that there's just a total difference in the cost that we have to deal with, then we'll have to address it accordingly in pricing, but we just don't do it on as-quick-a basis.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: If there is a negative thesis on Hormel, it is that higher hog prices would impact your earnings growth going forward. I guess what I'm just trying to figure out is going into fiscal '11, how big of a negative impact is it really? Is it enough to kind of
componenttext: If there is a negative thesis on Hormel, it is that higher hog prices would impact your earnings growth going forward. I guess what I'm just trying to figure out is going into fiscal '11, how big of a negative impact is it really? Is it enough to kind of slow your ability to hit your normal targets? Or is it just something that you can offset through other parts of your portfolio, either because the portfolio is very balanced or because you think that the pricing can eventually cover it?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I mean, we have not completed any sort of budgeting cycle yet for 2011. But I can give you a general sense. We've talked before that one environment for our company that provides some short-term challenges for certain units is when costs go up quickly, an
componenttext: I mean, we have not completed any sort of budgeting cycle yet for 2011. But I can give you a general sense. We've talked before that one environment for our company that provides some short-term challenges for certain units is when costs go up quickly, and we certainly have seen that in the pork area. And so sort of baked into our second half number here is the expectation that it's going to be a more challenging environment for Grocery Product and Refrigerated Foods. We do think some of the other segments can offset that substantially but that is out there. Our best outlook right now for 2011 would be along the lines of what you're describing, which is I would expect our team to react to the environmental change and we're either going to have to address pricing if there is a new higher cost level that is going to stay in place or if some of those costs recede somewhat, we should be in a position in 2011 to achieve our normal long-term growth objectives.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: So then just a modeling question then, so if we look at fiscal '10 and how it's kind of playing out, the first half of the year, you definitely over delivered on where you thought you would be. And as we get to the second half of the year, the comparisons
componenttext: So then just a modeling question then, so if we look at fiscal '10 and how it's kind of playing out, the first half of the year, you definitely over delivered on where you thought you would be. And as we get to the second half of the year, the comparisons are tougher, operating profit growth was very big in the second half of fiscal '09. So it'll be a comparison issue and maybe a little bit of a challenging environment because of the higher hog prices. It's kind of like a tale of two halves for fiscal '10.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's fair. But again, we try to run the business on the basis of the full year, and that was part of why we moved to annualized guidance by moving up our guidance range. Now is the second time we've done it this year. The midpoint of that range
componenttext: I think that's fair. But again, we try to run the business on the basis of the full year, and that was part of why we moved to annualized guidance by moving up our guidance range. Now is the second time we've done it this year. The midpoint of that range would be a solid 10% increase on an earnings-per-share basis over last year's results and a better increase than that on an operating profit basis, because you want to wash out the rabbi trust effect. And we're going to look at the year if we can deliver the second half the way we've described it as being a very successful year and one we can build on going forward.

componenttext: Ann, I'm afraid they haven't changed since last time. But certainly, as Jeff indicated before, we continue to look at opportunities to invest strategically either internally. Our CapEx spending has been lower. And I guided the full year a little bit lower because while we've got great projects in the pipeline, it seems to be that we're taking a little longer than I originally anticipated in getting some of those things done and equipment ordered and whatnot. So CapEx should be coming back online and getting back to more normalized levels in the back half of the year. So we look at acquisitions, investing in our own business, certainly, we're committed to our dividends, to our shareholders and share repurchase as well. So those seem to be the key.

componenttext: Jeff, it's been a while since I've heard you discuss the dynamics of your hog contracts. And I'm just wondering given the volatility of what we've been through, kind of from 30,000 feet if you could assess what you've accomplished, what you're seeing out there, if you think you're taking market share, if this environment is giving you an opportunity to continue to upgrade the quality of your producers in terms of their financial strengths and capabilities. Just kind of the picture as you see it over the progress you've made there?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Our hog contracts generally are based on markets. So it's usually a spread to the Western Cornbelt since that's where most of our hogs are sourced. So we really do kind of follow the market. We have been fortunate that the producers we've aligned ourselve
componenttext: Our hog contracts generally are based on markets. So it's usually a spread to the Western Cornbelt since that's where most of our hogs are sourced. So we really do kind of follow the market. We have been fortunate that the producers we've aligned ourselves with have had a lot of financial strength. We have some of the smaller operators have fallen on the wayside and they've got in over their heads and we're losing money. But generally, our producers have been stronger, and we continue to work with other producers that maybe aren't happy with their current packer that they're dealing with and have some opportunities there. So we feel very comfortable about the supply of hog for the future for Hormel and these are generally long-term contracts, five to 10 years.

componenttext: As I'd indicated in an answer to Ann earlier was, we have projects in the pipeline for CapEx. It's not for a lack of wanting to get things to do things. They just seem to be taking longer than I originally anticipated in my guidance. So I did pull it down for the full year. I think it's being conservative. But they don't seem to be happening as fast as I thought they would.
