headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: On MegaMex sales and your whole Mexican initiative, could you share with us what MegaMex Foods were, what do you expect them to be going forward, and could you give us more color on how Don Miguel will impact margins in that business or benefit margins in
componenttext: On MegaMex sales and your whole Mexican initiative, could you share with us what MegaMex Foods were, what do you expect them to be going forward, and could you give us more color on how Don Miguel will impact margins in that business or benefit margins in that business?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sales all told, if you count all these brands that we combine together with, the four-day over a year ago, and then you add on Don Miguel, we're talking about a business venture that's north of $300 million. So it's a significant investment for us in piec
componenttext: Sales all told, if you count all these brands that we combine together with, the four-day over a year ago, and then you add on Don Miguel, we're talking about a business venture that's north of $300 million. So it's a significant investment for us in piece of our portfolio. As I tried to articulate earlier in the comments, you're not going to see all those sales roll through Grocery Products sales because the Don Miguel portion is not going to be going through at least in the first year where we have to talk with a partner overtime as to what the best way is going to manage that aspect of the business. That's in part due to allow us to get our hands around Don Miguel. And in recognition of the fact that nearly half of Don Miguel sales are in the C-store channel, and that's not been our typical forte of our consumer products sales organization. And so we may have a hybrid approach, or we may have to bolster our skills within CPS for recovering C-stores. But that's something will chat with the current Don Miguel management and with our partner going forward.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Margins in that business, going forward are they going to be similar with Grocery Products because Don Miguel sales won't be included, but profits will be? I'm just trying to figure out how to model that segment?
componenttext: Margins in that business, going forward are they going to be similar with Grocery Products because Don Miguel sales won't be included, but profits will be? I'm just trying to figure out how to model that segment?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think for this upcoming year, that will certainly be a plus to Grocery Products. So instead of the 15% we ended up with this year, we'll start moving toward that 18% number. But it's not going to fully get you there.
componenttext: I think for this upcoming year, that will certainly be a plus to Grocery Products. So instead of the 15% we ended up with this year, we'll start moving toward that 18% number. But it's not going to fully get you there.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: You have a significant cash position and no debt, could you share with us your priorities in cash and how your M&A pipeline is looking?
componenttext: You have a significant cash position and no debt, could you share with us your priorities in cash and how your M&A pipeline is looking?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, Farha, this is Jody. Yes, we do have a significant amount of cash. Certainly, our announcement yesterday of substantial increase to our dividend is to somewhat address that, and also to recognize that we did have a very strong year and expect it to co
componenttext: Hi, Farha, this is Jody. Yes, we do have a significant amount of cash. Certainly, our announcement yesterday of substantial increase to our dividend is to somewhat address that, and also to recognize that we did have a very strong year and expect it to continue to have a strong year next year. So returning cash to shareholders, we repurchased shares in the fourth quarter for the full year to the tune of about $70 million. That remains to be another opportunity for excess cash. But really, it gets down to looking for those M&A opportunities and internal organic investments in our business. That's what's going to grow us then. There are seems to be a lot more deals that get announced in the news. I don't have anything to tell you today. We typically don't speculate about that.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Diane Geissler with CLSA.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Diane Geissler with CLSA.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the Grocery Products segment, that's a two-part question, so part one would be my accretion level on Don Miguel, it worked out to be about $0.06 or about 100 dips on the EBIT margin. Could you help me there? Am I in the ballpark? And my second question
componenttext: On the Grocery Products segment, that's a two-part question, so part one would be my accretion level on Don Miguel, it worked out to be about $0.06 or about 100 dips on the EBIT margin. Could you help me there? Am I in the ballpark? And my second question on Grocery Products, you've mentioned that because of the material inputs, you were taking some pricing. Could you give us some idea about your expectations, even if you want to speak directly to Grocery Products about how much you think pricing will add on the top line in fiscal 2011?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll take the second question first and then Jody's doing some math and maybe we can help you with the accretion. In terms of raw material inputs, we are going to take an action on SPAM. We've announced to ourselves an organizational price increase in the
componenttext: I'll take the second question first and then Jody's doing some math and maybe we can help you with the accretion. In terms of raw material inputs, we are going to take an action on SPAM. We've announced to ourselves an organizational price increase in the pipeline that will take effect at the beginning of the second quarter. On a company-wide basis, we're really kind of evaluating each portfolio and each area the business and looking at what consumer behavior has been, what the competitiveness has been like. I think when we take our pricing it's probably going to be in that 3% to 4% range, but we won't be taking on every item. So you can moderate that number downward somewhat to estimate what the impact the pricing would be on our overall year.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Diane, I think you may be including the full impact of Don Miguel in your estimation. And attributing it to Hormel when we have to share that with our partner.
componenttext: Diane, I think you may be including the full impact of Don Miguel in your estimation. And attributing it to Hormel when we have to share that with our partner.

componenttext: I guess maybe my assumptions regarding the margin structure in the business is too aggressive. So it's not margin structure would not be similar to the other products within your Grocery Products segment?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Clarification and then a question. Jody, I think you mentioned lower corn input cost in Jennie-O Turkey Store. Is that referring specifically to the hedging gain or even x the hedging gain which you have had favorable imports there?
componenttext: Clarification and then a question. Jody, I think you mentioned lower corn input cost in Jennie-O Turkey Store. Is that referring specifically to the hedging gain or even x the hedging gain which you have had favorable imports there?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say that their feed costs are driven by lower grain costs. And we kind of look at it, including whatever gains are flowing through, but remember they're is always that timeline because you're feeding the turkey for the full time of its life. So th
componenttext: I would say that their feed costs are driven by lower grain costs. And we kind of look at it, including whatever gains are flowing through, but remember they're is always that timeline because you're feeding the turkey for the full time of its life. So there are varying levels that go in there. And we really look at it as a total feed cost overall. So that was one of the drivers for them. The 7.3 is above and beyond that. That was unexpected, ineffectiveness gain that we had for the quarter.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, I always think you're a good window into the Foodservice world. We haven't really been hearing overly bullish commentary on Foodservice. But I'd love to hear what your thoughts are right now?
componenttext: Jeff, I always think you're a good window into the Foodservice world. We haven't really been hearing overly bullish commentary on Foodservice. But I'd love to hear what your thoughts are right now?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just came out from their national sales meeting, and their group has a good sense of optimizing. They understand it's still a challenging environment out there. But when you focus in on the branded value-added products, they were showing growth in the v
componenttext: I just came out from their national sales meeting, and their group has a good sense of optimizing. They understand it's still a challenging environment out there. But when you focus in on the branded value-added products, they were showing growth in the vast majority of those items through the latter half of the year and have expectations for those in 2011 .

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from the line of Robert Moskow from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: And the next question is from the line of Robert Moskow from Credit Suisse.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think what we try to get earlier was the notion that we think they can maintain the level that they were able to achieve during 2010 and expand it a little bit based on sales increases. But that after a couple of pretty solid growth years in a row, that
componenttext: I think what we try to get earlier was the notion that we think they can maintain the level that they were able to achieve during 2010 and expand it a little bit based on sales increases. But that after a couple of pretty solid growth years in a row, that we're not expecting the huge increases that we've seen in the past year. They've driven a lot of efficiencies within their operation, and I think they're now in a mode where the top line's going to be important for them in the long run to make sure they keep that momentum.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: As far as acquisitions, I know you can't discuss anything specific, but as far as possible leverage targets can you give us any color on that and what you'd be willing to go up to?
componenttext: As far as acquisitions, I know you can't discuss anything specific, but as far as possible leverage targets can you give us any color on that and what you'd be willing to go up to?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've talked before that we certainly feel we have a balance sheet that could hold upwards to $1 billion in debt, and we have $500 million of cash on our balance sheet and investments at this point. So but traditionally in the acquisition arena, we kind o
componenttext: We've talked before that we certainly feel we have a balance sheet that could hold upwards to $1 billion in debt, and we have $500 million of cash on our balance sheet and investments at this point. So but traditionally in the acquisition arena, we kind of focused on the $300 million plus or minus. So those are the areas.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Lindsay Drucker Mann with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Lindsay Drucker Mann with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was just hoping you could help me better understand the composition of your guidance. I know tax rate helps a little bit, but on the divisional level, maybe just talking to which divisions you expect to be particularly strong, especially if the accretio
componenttext: I was just hoping you could help me better understand the composition of your guidance. I know tax rate helps a little bit, but on the divisional level, maybe just talking to which divisions you expect to be particularly strong, especially if the accretion from Don Miguel is a bit modest and you're looking for a return to more normal or at least not necessarily peak margins in the Pork business?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: My expectation is that all five units will be up during 2011. I think we're looking at modest gains, low- to mid-single digits for Jennie-O Turkey Store and Refrigerated Foods. I think we're looking at a fairly typical gain from Specialty Foods based on o
componenttext: My expectation is that all five units will be up during 2011. I think we're looking at modest gains, low- to mid-single digits for Jennie-O Turkey Store and Refrigerated Foods. I think we're looking at a fairly typical gain from Specialty Foods based on our long-term guidance. So it's normally 10% but they're sort of weak, about roughly 2% so that high single-digit for them. Our expectations for international our solid double-digit growth and they have had a very strong set of years for about four or five years in a row and the last couple of years have not been as strong. So we're expecting them to get back on track and be able to generate that. And then Grocery, we're expecting a good year out of Grocery. We think they have decent solid momentum in their core portfolio anyways. And then you add to that the Kids Compleate, you added the momentum we had in MegaMex, you add our portion of the Don Miguel earnings. And then on top of that, we do expect to benefit from the move of the VALLEY FRESH canned chicken production into our Dubuque facility. That was part of the write down we took in the second quarter but we are now producing. You started that at the end of the fourth quarter and that will improve our cost picture for our chunk chicken line. So all the those things put together should be in the Grocery Products should be able to have a very strong year in 2011.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: As a follow up, I was hoping you guys, I know the final rule is probably a little ways out, but maybe just to give us a sense of how the dips to changes may affect your business.
componenttext: As a follow up, I was hoping you guys, I know the final rule is probably a little ways out, but maybe just to give us a sense of how the dips to changes may affect your business.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: It really will be highly dependent on how those final rules look. We're certainly in dialogues with the regulators, with our producers. Our producers are writing letters and attending hearings throughout the country. We think that many of the things in th
componenttext: It really will be highly dependent on how those final rules look. We're certainly in dialogues with the regulators, with our producers. Our producers are writing letters and attending hearings throughout the country. We think that many of the things in the articulated rules would be counterproductive to both our industry and the economy in general. But we'll just have to see where it ends up sorting out and how many of the restrictions really end up applying. We definitely are in the mode of relying upon contract, growing in both Jennie-O and in our hog operations. So it's a very important element for us going forward.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Todd Deviq with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Todd Deviq with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: You just kind of -- your question was my answer. That's something we're certainly looking at obviously we don't need the cash and we can defeat the note with the cash on hand. But given the current environment, we certainly take a look at the possibility
componenttext: You just kind of -- your question was my answer. That's something we're certainly looking at obviously we don't need the cash and we can defeat the note with the cash on hand. But given the current environment, we certainly take a look at the possibility of maybe doing a smaller offering.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our typical funding levels would be to find normal cost on a annual basis. We did make the additional contributions in 2010 to get us to fully-funded status. So our plans are in very good shape and we would just look at normal costs, which is in the $20 m
componenttext: Our typical funding levels would be to find normal cost on a annual basis. We did make the additional contributions in 2010 to get us to fully-funded status. So our plans are in very good shape and we would just look at normal costs, which is in the $20 million range.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from the line of Eric Larson with Soleil Securities.
componenttext: And the next question is from the line of Eric Larson with Soleil Securities.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you drill on a little bit further on the hog cut off margins, obviously, we've got pretty good demand, we've got recently strong exports. The tariff in Mexico didn't do anything to stem demand. You got very big good profit margins at the producer leve
componenttext: Can you drill on a little bit further on the hog cut off margins, obviously, we've got pretty good demand, we've got recently strong exports. The tariff in Mexico didn't do anything to stem demand. You got very big good profit margins at the producer level, and yet we're seeing very tight supplies. We're not seeing them expand the herd, and obviously there's some caution on the feed out costs with meal and corn prices where they are. Can you just summarize maybe more on the supply side, kind of give us an idea of how the producers might be looking at this current environment as to what they might do for either expansion plans or no expansion plans.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take a turn on the hog markets here. I'm not sure that I agree with your statement that the producers are in good shape. They had some periods of profitability. But with the recent run-up in grains, if they're not hedged on that, I would sense that
componenttext: Let me take a turn on the hog markets here. I'm not sure that I agree with your statement that the producers are in good shape. They had some periods of profitability. But with the recent run-up in grains, if they're not hedged on that, I would sense that they're probably not as profitable. Certainly not at the levels that they were earlier this year. I would expect that we should see about the same level of production in 2011. I guess it gets back to the demand side of the equation. And as you have indicated, even some of the negatives with the tariff markets and whatnot in Mexico, we still seem to have that strong demand. And that's something that I don't have the answer to.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Basically, everything you said right there, Jody, it sounds like you could have continued relatively strong cut off margins if producers really aren't willing to expand their herds at this point.
componenttext: Basically, everything you said right there, Jody, it sounds like you could have continued relatively strong cut off margins if producers really aren't willing to expand their herds at this point.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't sense that we're going to see large-scale expansion given the profitability for the producers at this point, so that's correct. I also don't know what consumers will do when they finally get passed through all the cost that need to go down to the
componenttext: I don't sense that we're going to see large-scale expansion given the profitability for the producers at this point, so that's correct. I also don't know what consumers will do when they finally get passed through all the cost that need to go down to the consumer level. And then you also have the competing proteins that would have an impact and if chicken starts to be a better value for the consumer, that could have some demand impacts. So I wish I could give you a definitive answer. I don't know. And as Jeff indicated in his response, it's something that we're just not counting on. But we've said that for a couple of quarters, too.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Ann Gurkin with Davenport.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Ann Gurkin with Davenport.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask about the consumer if you could comment on how you think health of consumer is right now, and what does Hormel need to do in the next several years to remain relevant or add value to the consumer perception of Hormel brands?
componenttext: Just wanted to ask about the consumer if you could comment on how you think health of consumer is right now, and what does Hormel need to do in the next several years to remain relevant or add value to the consumer perception of Hormel brands?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: The consumer is our reaction from our consumers to our products has been quite strong, but clearly the overall economy is mixed and still have a significant pockets of weakness. Our emphasis is in part on continuing to build the brand. We've had a steady
componenttext: The consumer is our reaction from our consumers to our products has been quite strong, but clearly the overall economy is mixed and still have a significant pockets of weakness. Our emphasis is in part on continuing to build the brand. We've had a steady effort against the Hormel brand over the last two to three years, and we'll continue that into 2011. We had an extra strong effort against the Jennie-O Turkey Store brand in the second half of 2010 and we're going to take on the wait-and-see approach as the level of advertising we go after the Jennie-O brand with in 2011. But our initial read on that advertising was we saw some very nice sales increases. Otherwise, continuing to be innovative with the products is important, and that ranges from brand-new products such as Kids Compleats or new versions of party trays to just kind of simple innovations even with existing franchises like our Hormel Chili franchise, simple things like putting easy-open ends on it and reducing the sodium level of the core product. And we had a very strong year with Hormel Chili last year, even with just simple innovations like that.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Mike Hamilton with RBC.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Mike Hamilton with RBC.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Congratulations on the year. Only in America can in active positions lead to a booking again, my boss going to be really impressed with that, referring to me of course. If you could just take a look back at the year and assess the progress you've made on
componenttext: Congratulations on the year. Only in America can in active positions lead to a booking again, my boss going to be really impressed with that, referring to me of course. If you could just take a look back at the year and assess the progress you've made on the value add side within your businesses.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm very happy with it. I was a little concern as we ended last year where we had lost momentum in sales we had a so-so third quarter and a poor fourth quarter in terms of sales. I think the team has really redoubled their efforts to make sure that we wer
componenttext: I'm very happy with it. I was a little concern as we ended last year where we had lost momentum in sales we had a so-so third quarter and a poor fourth quarter in terms of sales. I think the team has really redoubled their efforts to make sure that we were doing the right promotions with customers to introduce a couple of strategic new items and then the advertising, I think, supported it. We saw a ready very solid growth across most of our major value-added franchises as we ended the year, significant double-digit gains in grocery and Meat Products and Foodservice and the value-added Jennie-O portfolio. So I'm pretty pleased with it.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is a follow up from the line of Akshay Jagdale with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is a follow up from the line of Akshay Jagdale with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to again get a little bit more clarification on the pork markets, and thank you for your comments on that, Jody. But in your opinion, what's driving the higher cut out margin? Is it export or domestic demand?
componenttext: Just wanted to again get a little bit more clarification on the pork markets, and thank you for your comments on that, Jody. But in your opinion, what's driving the higher cut out margin? Is it export or domestic demand?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's been a combination of both. We've seen strong export demand. I believe that's weakening here lately, but earlier in the year we saw strong export demand. And then we've had great consumer demand for pork in the U.S. And it seems to be clearin
componenttext: I think it's been a combination of both. We've seen strong export demand. I believe that's weakening here lately, but earlier in the year we saw strong export demand. And then we've had great consumer demand for pork in the U.S. And it seems to be clearing. So certainly, the freezer stock inventories that came out today show that we're still down 2% year-over-year.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: So would you agree if I the say that because corn is where it is and what has happened in the producers side of it, which is they had two years of losses, that despite demand being strong, supplies sort of slower to react than it usually is, which is why
componenttext: So would you agree if I the say that because corn is where it is and what has happened in the producers side of it, which is they had two years of losses, that despite demand being strong, supplies sort of slower to react than it usually is, which is why maybe margins have sustained at this higher-level? Is that a fair would you agree or disagree with that statement?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Certainly, supply, we haven't seen expansion in the hog industry. Anecdotally, I understand that some of the producers are finding it difficult to get the financing that they may need. And some of the larger producers are kind of waiting to see where thes
componenttext: Certainly, supply, we haven't seen expansion in the hog industry. Anecdotally, I understand that some of the producers are finding it difficult to get the financing that they may need. And some of the larger producers are kind of waiting to see where these grain crops settle in at and to see what their business model will look like before they put anything else on the ground. So I am kind of going along with where the USDA sees hogs for 2011 at this point, which is basically flat.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: For Jeff on the Turkey side, what are your expectations in supply for next year on the turkey side? We've seen some of the exit numbers pickup, and with a good year, probably expect those numbers to continue to move up. But what are your expectations on t
componenttext: For Jeff on the Turkey side, what are your expectations in supply for next year on the turkey side? We've seen some of the exit numbers pickup, and with a good year, probably expect those numbers to continue to move up. But what are your expectations on the supply side, especially in light of what's going on with grains?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't have a full read on that. You've identified both the factors that people are weighing. I guess the best I can tell you is that we intend to hold the line on production.
componenttext: I don't have a full read on that. You've identified both the factors that people are weighing. I guess the best I can tell you is that we intend to hold the line on production.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We do have another follow-up from the line of Lindsay Drucker-Mann with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We do have another follow-up from the line of Lindsay Drucker-Mann with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010

componenttext: I had a question on International, if you think maybe you can give us a bit of color as to why you think that division from a profit growth perspective has log lagged what you think the normalized growth rate might be. And then in addition, does the Chinese initiatives curb domestic inflation have any bearing on your business there?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: The difficulty they've had the last couple of years has really been related to the run up in hog costs and in term in trend. That goes into SPAM. SPAM is a key item internationally. Their sales growth for SPAM has been fantastic. And in the long run, I'm
componenttext: The difficulty they've had the last couple of years has really been related to the run up in hog costs and in term in trend. That goes into SPAM. SPAM is a key item internationally. Their sales growth for SPAM has been fantastic. And in the long run, I'm very confident that, that building of that franchise is really going to generate some significant profit for that division. But we have to wait for a little bit more moderate situation and their pricing to catch up some pricing action and they've announced they're taking further pricing action. They also had benefited from really pretty good margins over the year in their Fresh Pork business and specialized items, but again, that got quite tight this year with the way the markets are. We're expecting a gradual improvement in that picture for them and then their momentum in these value-added items can drive the day for them. In terms of China, our China focuses primarily in-country with our two facilities, and we're really not seeing any impact on the business in there.

componenttext: We're thinking that it will be a little bit more moderate but that's that the key driver. That will help. We're expecting better results out of a couple of the partnership interests that we have in the Philippines and in other markets. We're continuing to invest in growing the brand in Japan. So we think those volume increases will be a driver as well.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to the Hormel Foods conference call for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2010. We released our results this morning before the market opened around 6:30 a.m. Central Time. If you did not receive a copy of the release, you can find it on
componenttext:
Good morning. Welcome to the Hormel Foods conference call for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2010. We released our results this morning before the market opened around 6:30 a.m. Central Time. If you did not receive a copy of the release, you can find it on our website at www.hormelfoods.com, under the Investors section. 
On our call today is Jeff Ettinger, Chairman of the Board, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jody Feragen, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Jeff will provide a review of the operating results for the quarter and the year, then Jody will provide a detailed financial results for the quarter. The line will be open for questions following Jody's remarks. 
I would ask that you please adhere to one question plus one follow-up question, and if you have further questions, you can always go to the back of the queue and likely we'll have an opportunity to answer that question as well. Campbell has a  conference call beginning at one hour after ours started and so we want to make sure we finish on-time. Thank you for your cooperation on that. 
An audio replay of this call will be available beginning at 10:30 a.m. Central Time today, November 23, 2010. The dial in number is (800)406-7325, and the access code is 4384165. It will also be posted to our website and archived for one year. 
Before we get started with the results of the quarter, I need to reference the Safe Harbor statement. Some of the comments made today will be forward-looking and are made under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from those expressed in or implied by the statements we will be making. Among the factors that may affect the operating results of the company are fluctuations in the cost and availability of raw materials and market conditions for finished products. Please refer to Pages 32 through 38 in the company's 10-Q for the quarter ended July 25, 2010, for more details. It can be accessed on our website. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Jeff.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. We are pleased to report another excellent quarter. Earnings per share for Q4 increased to $0.90, up a solid 17% from a year ago. For the full year, our U.S. GAAP earnings per share were $2.92, up 15% from last year. We did benefit
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. We are pleased to report another excellent quarter. Earnings per share for Q4 increased to $0.90, up a solid 17% from a year ago. For the full year, our U.S. GAAP earnings per share were $2.92, up 15% from last year. We did benefit from having 14 weeks in the quarter compared to 13 weeks a year ago. 
Our goal for fiscal 2010, coming off a very strong earnings year but on declining sales, was to restore our top line growth. Our sales momentum from the previous two quarters accelerated in the fourth quarter. Total company sales for the quarter were $2.1 billion, up a substantial 23% from a year ago. As a result, we exceeded the $7 billion level in sales for the first time in our company's history, and all five segments contributed to the sales gain. 
I will now take you through each segment. Our Grocery Products group reported a segment profit decrease of 6% and a sales gain of 24% for the fourth quarter. For the year, segment operating profit was down 4%, and sales were up 13%. Segment profit during the quarter and for the year was adversely impacted by higher raw material cost and the Q2 charge related to the VALLEY FRESH plant closing. Notwithstanding this profit decrease, we were pleased to see the solid sales results delivered by the Grocery Products unit and our consumer products sales organization. Sales were driven higher by Hormel Chili and hash, Compleats microwave meals and strong sales growth across much of our MegaMex Foods product portfolio. 
Last quarter, I said I would provide more clarity around the impact of MegaMex Foods on the Grocery Products operating margins. Our operating margins for the year was 15%. Without MegaMex Foods sales, it would have been 18%. The absence of CARAPELLI sales also improved operating margins for Grocery Products. Going forward, because Don Miguel sales initially will not be reflected in our segment top line results, the profits on those sales should improve the reported operating margin for Grocery Products.
Our Refrigerated Foods group delivered an outstanding quarter with operating profit of 22% and sales up 26%. For the full year, segment profit was up 22% and sales increased by 11%. We continue to benefit from the unusually high pork operating margins in Q4, offsetting the margin squeeze on our value-added products due to higher raw material costs. 
Our Meat Products group posted large sales gains across much of their product portfolio, led by sales of Hormel Party Tray and Pepperoni and Natural Choice deli meats. Our Foodservice group also contributed to the strong top line picture, led by sales of Café H ethnic meats, Natural Choice deli meats and AUSTIN BLUES BBQ products. I continue to be pleased with the job our team has done with the integration of the Country Crock line of side dishes. This acquisition has contributed nicely to our results.
Our Jennie-O Turkey Store segment completed a very strong year with an excellent quarter, with segment profits growing 90% and sales up 19% for the quarter. For the full year, segment profit was up 65% and sales increased 7%. Results of Jennie-O were driven by efficiencies throughout their supply chain and in their operations. Jennie-O also benefited from higher commodity turkey meat prices and lower feed costs. Included in the large Q4 segment profit increase was a much larger than usual hedging gain, amounting to an incremental $7.3 million, about which Jody will provide more explanation.
You will recall we chose to roll out an enhanced advertising campaign for the Jennie-O brand during the second quarter half of 2010. We believe the campaign contributed to the double-digit sales growth throughout our value-added businesses at Jennie-O Turkey Store, led by retail turkey burgers and tray pack products.
The Specialty Foods unit reported a segment profit decline of 6% on a sales increase of 12% for the quarter. Improved sales of sugar, sugar substitutes, nutritional jars and dysphasia products were unable to offset higher raw material costs impacting our Specialty Products business. Notwithstanding the off quarter from a segment profit standpoint, for the full year segment profit for Specialty Foods is up 18% and sales grew 10%, contributing nicely to our overall company success in 2010. 
In our All Other segment, which consists primarily of our Hormel Foods International business, Q4 segment profit was down 3%, and sales were up 33%. Higher sales of our SPAM family of products were unable to offset higher raw material costs, impacting export product margins. For the full year, segment profit was down 5% and sales were up 13%.
Looking at fiscal 2011, we should continue to benefit from the solid top line momentum shown in the past three quarters. For example, strong sales of our Hormel Party Trays and Hormel Pepperoni items and our Refrigerated Foods segment will grow our presence in the home occasion and snack categories. We have many other growth platforms that we believe will help drive our results in fiscal 2011. All told, we expect to achieve sales gains in all five segments in fiscal 2011.
We also expect to generate segment profit gains in all five segments in fiscal 2011, though our current expectation is that both Refrigerated Foods and Jennie-O Turkey Store may see much more modest segment profit growth in 2011 after such substantial gains in 2010. We will start fiscal 2011 with the continued benefit of historically high pork operating margins in our Refrigerated Foods segment, but we do not presently expect these historically high margins to continue. On the other hand, we believe that our initiatives with Mexican food and the addition of Don Miguel will help drive strong results in our Grocery Products segment in 2011.
Headwinds to our outlook for 2011 include continued higher raw material cost, significantly higher grain costs and the absence late in the year of both the extra 53rd week and the hedge gain at Jennie-O Turkey Store. In reaction to the higher raw material costs, we are embarking upon a program of strategic and modest price increases with a number of our products. After taking into account all of these significant factors, we are setting our fiscal 2011 earnings guidance range at $3.10 to $3.20 per share. 
At this time, I will turn the call over to Jody Feragen to discuss the financial information relating to the fourth quarter and fiscal 2010.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeff. Good morning, everyone. Earnings for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2010 totaled $121.1 million or $0.90 per share compared to $103.9 million or $0.77 per share a year ago. U.S. GAAP earnings for the 12 months of fiscal 2010 totaled $395.6
componenttext:
Thank you, Jeff. Good morning, everyone. Earnings for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2010 totaled $121.1 million or $0.90 per share compared to $103.9 million or $0.77 per share a year ago. U.S. GAAP earnings for the 12 months of fiscal 2010 totaled $395.6 million or $2.92 per share compared to $342.8 million or $2.53 per share a year ago. 
Adjusted earnings for the full year totaled $409 million or $3.02 per share. Adjusted earnings exclude onetime charges in the second quarter relating to the closure of the VALLEY FRESH plant and the tax charges primarily related to the new healthcare laws. 
Dollar sales for the fourth quarter totaled $2.1 billion compared to $1.7 billion last year, a 23% increase. For the full year, dollar sales were $7.2 billion, an 11% increase from last year. Volume for the fourth quarter was 1.3 billion pounds up 14% from fiscal 2009. Year-to-date, volume was 4.8 billion pounds, up 5% from fiscal 2009.
As Jeff mentioned earlier, we reported an incremental gain of $7.3 million in our Jennie-O segment relating to our open hedge position. We enter into futures contracts and swaps to hedge our grain cost. As required by hedge accounting rules, we've periodically measured the effectiveness of these instruments. The effective gains and losses are deferred, but the ineffective portion becomes a current gain or loss. The recent rapid increase in corn and soybean prices caused the ineffective gain to be much larger than we've typically experienced.
Selling, general and administrative expenses in the fourth quarter were 8.1% of sales compared to 8.5% last year. Year-to-date, selling, general and administrative expenses were 8.4% of sales compared to 8.7% last year. We expect selling, general and administrative expenses to be approximately 8.5% of sales for next year. 
Interest and investment income was $2.4 million for the fourth quarter compared to $2.2 million last year. Year-to-date, interest and investment income was $4.6 million compared to $19.6 million last year when favorable market returns on our rabbi trust investments drove our investment income higher. 
Interest expense for the quarter was $7 million compared to $6.7 million last year. Year-to-date, interest expense was $26.6 million, down from $28 million last year. We expect interest expense to be approximately $20 million to $23 million for fiscal 2011. Our effective tax rate in the fourth quarter was 34.8% versus 34% in fiscal 2009. The year-to-date effective tax rate is 36% compared to 34.5% last year. For fiscal 2011, we expect the effective tax rate to be between 35% and 36%.
The basic weighted average number of shares outstanding for the fourth quarter and full year was 133 million shares. The diluted weighted average number of shares outstanding for the fourth quarter and full year was 135 million shares. We repurchased 370,000 shares of common stock during the fourth quarter, and we have 4.4 million shares remaining to be purchased from the 5 million share authorization in place. 
Depreciation and amortization for the quarter was $33.5 million compared to $33.1 million last year. For the full year, depreciation and amortization was $126 million compared to $127 million last year. We expect depreciation and amortization to be about $125 million in fiscal 2011. Our $350 million bond due in June of 2011 is classified as a current obligation, so we carried no long-term debt at the end of the quarter. 
During the quarter, we made a $50.2 million contribution to our pension plan for a total of $70.3 million for the year. We invested $76 million in our MegaMex joint venture in the fourth quarter to facilitate the Don Miguel acquisition. Capital expenditures for the quarter totaled $26 million flat with last year. For the full year, capital expenditures totaled $90 million compared with $97 million last year. For fiscal 2011, we expect CapEx to be approximately $120 million to $130 million.
At this time, I will turn the call over to the operator for the question-and-answer portion of the call. Operator?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  And our first question is from the line of Akshay Jagdale with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  And our first question is from the line of Akshay Jagdale with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to, Jeff, if I may just talk a little bit about the Processing business and Refrigerated Foods and Others, always a lot of questions. But it seems like just throughout the industry, there's been above average margins in the Processing business
componenttext: Just wanted to, Jeff, if I may just talk a little bit about the Processing business and Refrigerated Foods and Others, always a lot of questions. But it seems like just throughout the industry, there's been above average margins in the Processing business, and even though you have a higher value-added portion, you've been benefiting from that and you are continuing to say that you don't expect this to sustain itself, these higher margins. Can you talk about why that's the case and then why do you expect margins not to be sustainable? And maybe even talk about why they are so high today?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think our outlook is that we're not counting on it. Just a couple of years ago or not even to full years ago, we were in the exact opposite situation and looking at negative cut evens and substantially below-average cut evens. I guess we've been in the
componenttext: I think our outlook is that we're not counting on it. Just a couple of years ago or not even to full years ago, we were in the exact opposite situation and looking at negative cut evens and substantially below-average cut evens. I guess we've been in the business a while we see these things swing. Now is it possible where it's some kind of level of a new norm? Yes, that's possible, but we're not banking on that in our 2011 guidance. Over time, if the Processing margins become more moderate and as we take pricing action to catch up with where the pork market has moved, we expect our value-added items to shine through and to be the major growth vehicle for Refrigerated Foods.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: So why do you think it could be a new normal if it is? I mean can you just -- it's not really clear to all of us, I think, on where we said today as to why margins are in fact higher. I mean, we see a much tighter supply-and-demand situation here in the U
componenttext: So why do you think it could be a new normal if it is? I mean can you just -- it's not really clear to all of us, I think, on where we said today as to why margins are in fact higher. I mean, we see a much tighter supply-and-demand situation here in the U.S., but why should it be sustained? I mean I'm just trying to get your sense of where we fall on that. You just mentioned that it could be a new norm. Can you help us understand why that could be the case?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I said it could be. But I also said that if you look at it based on what our guidance has been formulated against, we don't think it is. I would have sat here three or four years ago and been fairly astonished at corn regularly now being in the $5 r
componenttext: Well, I said it could be. But I also said that if you look at it based on what our guidance has been formulated against, we don't think it is. I would have sat here three or four years ago and been fairly astonished at corn regularly now being in the $5 range too. Our best guess right now is that this is still a somewhat temporal run-up that it will eventually moderate back down to a more normal level. But given that we told you in the last two quarters also, and it outlasted our expectations that time, I guess I'm just being a little more cautious in terms of being a know-all CEO in terms of where this market goes. In the long run, again, it just all gets back to we try to figure out what the likely input cost is going to be and then turn loose our Foodservice and Meat Products group to sell value-added products against that cost environment.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Ken Zaslow with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Ken Zaslow with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about what changes you've made to SPAM and Compleats to regain some sales momentum and my follow up just with that is are there channels that you are outperforming? Still, the retail take away doesn't seem as good as what you're putting up, s
componenttext: Can you talk about what changes you've made to SPAM and Compleats to regain some sales momentum and my follow up just with that is are there channels that you are outperforming? Still, the retail take away doesn't seem as good as what you're putting up, so I'm assuming it might be an alternative channel. If you could just talk to those two issues that would be great.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: SPAM to me, I really haven't viewed that as a problem anytime during the year. I mean we had a very strong sales in 2009. It's bounced around a little bit more in 2010. But in the long run, we think that's going to be a nice steady contributor for us and
componenttext: SPAM to me, I really haven't viewed that as a problem anytime during the year. I mean we had a very strong sales in 2009. It's bounced around a little bit more in 2010. But in the long run, we think that's going to be a nice steady contributor for us and that's what it was during the fourth quarter. Compleats, we were pleased to see a turnaround in Compleats. One quarter to me doesn't -- I don't take full comfort in that, okay, the job is done. I am excited by the new product offering that the Grocery Products marketing team and sales organization is bringing to the market, which is Kids Compleats, items that need the USDA definition for healthy products for children. And so that we hope will stimulate expanded growth during 2011 for those lines. To your second question, without a doubt, there is a difference from brand to brand as to how much of our business is in our reported channel versus non-reported channels. I don't want to get too specific with it, but you did happen to bring up both the examples you bought up have higher than normal sales in the unreported channels.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Christina McGlone with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Christina McGlone with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, just on Jennie-O, Jeff, it was a great quarter and looking into '11 you talked about higher year-over-year profit growth still moderating. And I'm just curious, I know sometimes you're reluctant to talk about it and you talk about your typical he
componenttext: I guess, just on Jennie-O, Jeff, it was a great quarter and looking into '11 you talked about higher year-over-year profit growth still moderating. And I'm just curious, I know sometimes you're reluctant to talk about it and you talk about your typical hedge position, but you talked about the gain in the quarter. I'm wondering what your coverage is like going into fiscal '11 on grains. And then also it looks like I guess because of the strong profitability, you're seeing excess up pretty strongly over the last six weeks so if we're facing higher production and higher grain costs next year, it would be difficult to grow EBIT year-over-year.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: On a coverage basis, I mean we're still kind of in our normal articulated guidance range that will cover our internal corn and soy needs in the 25% to 75% range. I mean we'll acknowledge that we're on the upper side of the 50% rather than the lower side.
componenttext: On a coverage basis, I mean we're still kind of in our normal articulated guidance range that will cover our internal corn and soy needs in the 25% to 75% range. I mean we'll acknowledge that we're on the upper side of the 50% rather than the lower side. We did think there was more upside risk heading into 2011 than there was downside opportunity. And so it's up to -- that will help moderate some of the pricing actions that Jennie-O Turkey Store has to take in 2011, but it won't eliminate them altogether. And indeed if we don't get released in the market in the long run, they'll probably have to be right back out there heading into 2012 looking at another step in their pricing. But that's something we need to do in terms of managing our customer relationships and consumer reaction to that. In terms of the commodity markets, I mean clearly, they are quite high right now. We don't sell a lot of breast meat on the commodity markets. So that element of the composition is less significant to us. But the hi-fi meat markets are certainly beneficial to Jennie-O and we expect that to be a positive for them in 2011.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: On MegaMex sales and your whole Mexican initiative, could you share with us kind of what MegaMex sales were? What you expect them to be going forward? And could you give us more color on how Don Miguel will impact margins in that business or benefit margi
componenttext: On MegaMex sales and your whole Mexican initiative, could you share with us kind of what MegaMex sales were? What you expect them to be going forward? And could you give us more color on how Don Miguel will impact margins in that business or benefit margins in that business?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sales all told, if you count everything in all the brands that we've combined together with Herdez Del Fuerte the four-day over a year ago, and then you add on Don Miguel, we're talking about a business venture that's north of $300 million. So it's a sign
componenttext: Sales all told, if you count everything in all the brands that we've combined together with Herdez Del Fuerte the four-day over a year ago, and then you add on Don Miguel, we're talking about a business venture that's north of $300 million. So it's a significant investment for us and piece of our portfolio. As I tried to articulate it earlier in the comments, I mean you're not going to see all those sales roll through Grocery Products sales because the Don Miguel portion is not going to be going through at least in the first year and we'll have to talk with a partner over time as to what's the best way is to manage that aspect of the business. That's in part to allow us to get our hands around Don Miguel. And in part it's in recognition of the fact that nearly half of Don Miguel sales are in the C-store channel, and that's not been our typical forte of our consumer products sales organization. And so we may have a hybrid approach or we may have to bolster our skills within CPS for recovering C-stores. But that's something we'll chat with the current Don Miguel management and with our partner going forward.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then margins in that business, going forward are they going to be similar to Grocery Products because Don Miguel sales won't be included but profits will be? I'm just trying to figure out how to model that segment?
componenttext: And then margins in that business, going forward are they going to be similar to Grocery Products because Don Miguel sales won't be included but profits will be? I'm just trying to figure out how to model that segment?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think for this upcoming year, that will certainly be a plus to Grocery Products. And so instead of the 15% we ended up with this year, we will start moving toward that 18% number. But it's not going to fully get you there.
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think for this upcoming year, that will certainly be a plus to Grocery Products. And so instead of the 15% we ended up with this year, we will start moving toward that 18% number. But it's not going to fully get you there.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: You have a significant cash position and no debt, could you share with us your priorities in cash and how your M&A pipeline is looking?
componenttext: You have a significant cash position and no debt, could you share with us your priorities in cash and how your M&A pipeline is looking?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Farha, this is Jody. Yes, we do have a significant amount of cash. Certainly, our announcement yesterday of substantial increase to our dividend is to somewhat address that. And also to recognize that we did have a very strong year and expect it to contin
componenttext: Farha, this is Jody. Yes, we do have a significant amount of cash. Certainly, our announcement yesterday of substantial increase to our dividend is to somewhat address that. And also to recognize that we did have a very strong year and expect it to continue to have a strong year next year. So returning cash to shareholders, we repurchased shares in the fourth quarter for the full year to the tune of about $70 million. That remains to be another opportunity for excess cash. But really, it gets down to looking for those M&A opportunities and internal organic investments in our business. That's what's going to grow us then. There seems to be a lot more deals that get announced in the news. I don't have anything to tell you today. We typically don't speculate about that.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010

componenttext: Just on the Grocery Products segment I see a two-part question. So part one would be my accretion level on Don Miguel, it worked out to be about $0.06 or about 100 DPS on the EBIT margin. Could you help me there? Am I in the ballpark? And the second question on Grocery Products would be, you've mentioned that because of the raw material inputs you were taking some pricing. Could you give us some idea about your expectations, even if you don't want to speak directly to Grocery Products about how much you think pricing will add on the top line in fiscal 2011?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll take the second question first and Jody's doing some math and maybe -- I'll finish the first question on accretion. In terms of raw material inputs, we are going to take an action on SPAM. We've announced to ourselves the organizational price increas
componenttext: I'll take the second question first and Jody's doing some math and maybe -- I'll finish the first question on accretion. In terms of raw material inputs, we are going to take an action on SPAM. We've announced to ourselves the organizational price increase on that product line that will kick in effective at the beginning of the second quarter. On a company-wide basis, we're really kind of evaluating each portfolio and each area the business and looking at what consumer behavior has been, what the competitives has been like. I think when we take pricing it's probably going to be in that 3% to 4% range, but we won't be taking on every item. And so you can moderate that number downwards somewhat to estimate what the impact the pricing would be on our overall year.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Diane, I think you may be including the full impact of Don Miguel in your estimation. And attributing it to Hormel when we have to share that with our partner.
componenttext: Diane, I think you may be including the full impact of Don Miguel in your estimation. And attributing it to Hormel when we have to share that with our partner.

componenttext: So I guess maybe my assumptions regarding the margin structure in the business were too aggressive. The margin structure would not be similar to the other products within your Grocery Products segment?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 23, 2010
