componenttextpreview: I don't have a profit breakdown for you. I think we have talked in the past that approximately 75% of our sales go out in a form that we consider to be the value-added products.
componenttext: I don't have a profit breakdown for you. I think we have talked in the past that approximately 75% of our sales go out in a form that we consider to be the value-added products.

componenttext: But I mean, am I right? I guess let me just think about the historical range anywhere from -- I always thought it was anywhere between 50%, 60% of the total profits to 120% of the total profits of that business would be value-added. Would that be a right range?

componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, it clearly, and we describe what the percentage of sales was value-added and we do expect that the value-added items should attain a better profit margin and a more reliable profit margin than the commodity side.
componenttext: Well, I mean, it clearly, and we describe what the percentage of sales was value-added and we do expect that the value-added items should attain a better profit margin and a more reliable profit margin than the commodity side.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Akshay Jagdale [KeyBanc Capital Markets Inc.].
componenttext: And the next question comes from Akshay Jagdale [KeyBanc Capital Markets Inc.].

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Just one question on Grocery Products, and if I can another one on Turkey. In Grocery Products, it seems like the margins sequentially came down. Looks like that's the piece of your business that got most impacted by higher costs. Can you talk about how m
componenttext: Just one question on Grocery Products, and if I can another one on Turkey. In Grocery Products, it seems like the margins sequentially came down. Looks like that's the piece of your business that got most impacted by higher costs. Can you talk about how much of that is a timing issue? And also, the volumes were really strong again and I may have missed your commentary on that, so if you could comment on those two things.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: For Grocery Products?
componenttext: For Grocery Products?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Akshay, I do think that for second quarter results, you saw a more pronounced impact on the cost increase on their side of the business. We did feel the same impact in certain elements of the Refrigerated Foods portfolio, but they have the offset of the h
componenttext: Akshay, I do think that for second quarter results, you saw a more pronounced impact on the cost increase on their side of the business. We did feel the same impact in certain elements of the Refrigerated Foods portfolio, but they have the offset of the hog cutouts to dissipate that somewhat. Items that are pork-based items, particularly our SPAM luncheon meat or Hormel Bacon Bits did see early steep increases in the raw material costs during the quarter and that did compress the margins then to a lower level than what we had been generating in the prior quarter and even the prior same quarter of last year. In terms of sales, Grocery Products overall did generate positive sales for the quarter. As I mentioned, if you sort out the discontinued business, the CARAPELLI, and you put aside the new franchises that we joined to the company through the MegaMex venture, the net effect of those two would be to flatten out GP [Grocery Products] sales, so it was kind of a mixed bag again within their portfolio. Chili did well. Hash did well. The Mexican products did well. Compleats was sort of back to even, which was just trending the direction we need it to trend, but we did see softer sales of some of the other canned items, which is SPAM and Dinty Moore this quarter, and the chunk meat items also were a little bit off.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And just one follow-up if I can on Turkey. I know Farha asked something to this extent, but if I look at the seasonality in your business -- obviously, 4Q and I believe 1Q for your fiscal year -- the best seasonal quarters for Turkey and the highest margi
componenttext: And just one follow-up if I can on Turkey. I know Farha asked something to this extent, but if I look at the seasonality in your business -- obviously, 4Q and I believe 1Q for your fiscal year -- the best seasonal quarters for Turkey and the highest margin on quarterly basis in those quarters is around 13.5%. It seems as though turkey, much like chicken, is set up pretty well right now, supply-demand wise, and you have some momentum on the profit margins going in. I mean, do you see this being -- 4Q could be a record profit year for turkey? I mean, the profit should trend up, right?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, without giving you a specific number in terms of net margin for the division, it clearly would be our position that, as we talked about our balanced model, that as we feel a little bit of pressure in the Grocery and Refrigerated segments for their va
componenttext: Yes, without giving you a specific number in terms of net margin for the division, it clearly would be our position that, as we talked about our balanced model, that as we feel a little bit of pressure in the Grocery and Refrigerated segments for their value-added items with the spike in pork costs, we do feel we have an offset in place with more favorable conditions and solid results through Jennie-O. So it would be correct that we should be able to trend upward from what we delivered this quarter on a quarterly basis.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Diane Geissler [Credit Agricole Securities].
componenttext: And the next question comes from Diane Geissler [Credit Agricole Securities].

componenttext: Our average hog cost this year was about $10 a live hundredweight more than 2009.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Is that a first half or a second quarter number?
componenttext: Is that a first half or a second quarter number?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: That's a second quarter number. Yes, about $10 over what we paid in the second quarter of 2009. I actually think that we're going to see hog prices kind of stay at this elevated level, but perhaps not trend up too much higher. I haven't put a lot of incre
componenttext: That's a second quarter number. Yes, about $10 over what we paid in the second quarter of 2009. I actually think that we're going to see hog prices kind of stay at this elevated level, but perhaps not trend up too much higher. I haven't put a lot of increase in the back half of the year. I do think that after our fiscal year, we'll probably see them come down quite a bit. I have a feeling that these are attractive prices for producers and that some of those empty sow stalls will now start filling up.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And then, I guess, for Jeff, you talked a little bit about seeing a recovery in Foodservice. I guess we could look at your portfolio and say you probably had some brands that did very well with the value-conscious consumer. Can you just talk about what yo
componenttext: And then, I guess, for Jeff, you talked a little bit about seeing a recovery in Foodservice. I guess we could look at your portfolio and say you probably had some brands that did very well with the value-conscious consumer. Can you just talk about what you expect over the next six months, if we do see a shift out of retail into Foodservice, what that means for your portfolio. And I guess, even within the Grocery Products, I would guess Compleats would do a little bit better, but SPAM would be a little bit weaker, but I'd like to hear what you're nearby forecast is, so say, in the next six months for your product portfolio.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, we're certainly seeing more favorable signs in the Foodservice environment. I mean, if you look at kind of total sales for Hormel Foodservice for example, they were flat for the quarter. On the branded or more highly valued-added items, we saw some
componenttext: Okay, we're certainly seeing more favorable signs in the Foodservice environment. I mean, if you look at kind of total sales for Hormel Foodservice for example, they were flat for the quarter. On the branded or more highly valued-added items, we saw some gains. And we had more territories up than were down, and that was an encouraging sign versus prior years. We would expect that trend to gradually accelerate. I guess we don't feel that -- we're not hearing from the Foodservice marketplace that the clouds have all parted and everything is excellent now. But if we do experience a shift where people start going out a little bit more often and businesses start attending a few more conferences, et cetera, we're certainly well-positioned to take advantage of that. We have Foodservice elements in four of our five operating segments, and they're all poised with good sales organizations and with good products hopefully to deliver against that audience. Within the grocery environment -- we’re not talking just Grocery Products, but grocery stores -- our impression has been that the recession has had mixed results. I mean we clearly saw some benefit to the traditional canned franchises, for a time there where almost all of those items were up. This quarter was more mixed in that regard, with Chili and Hash up and Dinty Moore and SPAM down. But we also did lose some momentum in our convenience items, both Compleats and our refrigerated entrées during last year. And so if consumers gain more confidence and the economy starts looking better, we do expect those franchises to improve.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Tim Ramey [D.A. Davidson & Co.].
componenttext: And the next question comes from Tim Ramey [D.A. Davidson & Co.].

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, the improvement in Specialty was impressive, and I'm wondering if there's any new product activity or new activity for new co-pack activity for customers there or if that's just kind of a steady-state improvement.
componenttext: Jeff, the improvement in Specialty was impressive, and I'm wondering if there's any new product activity or new activity for new co-pack activity for customers there or if that's just kind of a steady-state improvement.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Specialty has seen solid growth, and that's the one piece of our business that does have some private label involvement, the Specialty Products group. And they steadily increased their business, both in the traditional items they've been in the past
componenttext: Well, Specialty has seen solid growth, and that's the one piece of our business that does have some private label involvement, the Specialty Products group. And they steadily increased their business, both in the traditional items they've been in the past such as gelatin, but also some canned meat items, and so that is contributing to results. The Diamond Crystal group has found ways to continue to grow their business even during the recession. They sell in many cases to a different group of Foodservice operators than the meat side of our business traditionally focuses upon. And then one other element that helped us this quarter was last year we had kind of a lag effect or a negative effect from the Century Foods operation as they had lost some significant business, and they've done a nice job of replacing that business and getting back to a more traditional margins for them. So all three components are working well right now, and our outlook for the second half would be for that to continue.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And just a quick follow-up on the Jennie-O business. I don't know that you said it; I'm scrambling here. Did you say what your unit performance was there? And do you expect -- I mean, I know you've cut production there. All proteins have essentially been
componenttext: And just a quick follow-up on the Jennie-O business. I don't know that you said it; I'm scrambling here. Did you say what your unit performance was there? And do you expect -- I mean, I know you've cut production there. All proteins have essentially been cut, but what should we expect for the rest of the year on sort of your unit performance there?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I want to make sure when you say unit performance, what...
componenttext: I want to make sure when you say unit performance, what...

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Tonnage, I guess?
componenttext: Tonnage, I guess?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, total sales for Jennie-O were up 1%. The value-added portion was up more than that, and that's the game plan. I mean we have cut production over time. Those production cuts are starting to lap the time when we cut them and so you won't see th
componenttext: Yes, I mean, total sales for Jennie-O were up 1%. The value-added portion was up more than that, and that's the game plan. I mean we have cut production over time. Those production cuts are starting to lap the time when we cut them and so you won't see the declines going forward as much in terms of total tonnage, but the focus continues to be driving more products into the value-added area, and we saw really kind of very solid sales from all three of the value-added groups at Jennie-O.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Christina McGlone [Deutsche Bank AG].
componenttext: And the next question comes from Christina McGlone [Deutsche Bank AG].

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, you talked about flat sales in Grocery without the acquisitions and dispositions. What would volumes have been, just because I'm curious what the pricing mix is and the core price mix in that division?
componenttext: Jeff, you talked about flat sales in Grocery without the acquisitions and dispositions. What would volumes have been, just because I'm curious what the pricing mix is and the core price mix in that division?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: My recollection is that it'd be fairly similar, again, excluding those items. If any of the folks in Austin have a different number, please go ahead and chime in.
componenttext: My recollection is that it'd be fairly similar, again, excluding those items. If any of the folks in Austin have a different number, please go ahead and chime in.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, volume was down just a little bit more than flat, so it would've been -- the volume was a little bit more negative. But you get into all the mix issues, so that's kind of a difficult one.
componenttext: Jeff, volume was down just a little bit more than flat, so it would've been -- the volume was a little bit more negative. But you get into all the mix issues, so that's kind of a difficult one.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: So I guess the question is: Given the raw material increase, what do you think the outlook is for pricing in Grocery? And what do you think the retail and consumer response will be?
componenttext: So I guess the question is: Given the raw material increase, what do you think the outlook is for pricing in Grocery? And what do you think the retail and consumer response will be?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, for the Grocery items, we are going to take a little bit of a wait-and-see approach. I mean, we certainly knew that this spike was coming, but we're still not clear on how long it's going to last. When we take pricing on our branded items, both of t
componenttext: Well, for the Grocery items, we are going to take a little bit of a wait-and-see approach. I mean, we certainly knew that this spike was coming, but we're still not clear on how long it's going to last. When we take pricing on our branded items, both of them, Grocery and the Meat Product portfolio, we want to have a reliable price out there in the marketplace that then we can promote against. And so we've not made a call at this time yet as to whether that group needs to be looking at pricing on those specific items. As we move closer into the fall and we have a better look as to whether the hog market is going to be as Jody described, and potentially receding back a bit or whether we're at a new level, and then we'd have to make that call.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And Jeff, I'm curious about the acquisition pipeline because I know last year, you were saying that they were distressed assets on the block, but that's not really what Hormel looks at. But I'm thinking now there could be higher quality companies that sor
componenttext: And Jeff, I'm curious about the acquisition pipeline because I know last year, you were saying that they were distressed assets on the block, but that's not really what Hormel looks at. But I'm thinking now there could be higher quality companies that sort of fit in your profile that may be motivated by changes in tax laws to sell, so I'm wondering if the acquisition pipeline is more encouraging?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it'd be correct to say that the folks that we say were on the sidelines last year for valuation or economic reasons might be more encouraged now by the current environment. We've been probably just as active as ever in terms of exploring ways to g
componenttext: I think it'd be correct to say that the folks that we say were on the sidelines last year for valuation or economic reasons might be more encouraged now by the current environment. We've been probably just as active as ever in terms of exploring ways to grow our business and utilize the cash that we know we have on hand, and so we're certainly actively exploring things, but we don't have anything to announce at this point. It's the confluence of willing seller, willing buyer, the right value and the right strategic fit that need to come together and we’ve had times in the past few years where we've had several of those kind of things come together at once and other times where we go a stretch without one.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Eric Larson [Soleil Securities Group].
componenttext: And the next question comes from Eric Larson [Soleil Securities Group].

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: My question relates to the protein markets right now. Actually, the hog markets have been benefiting quite nicely from a very strong ham export market. It seems like there was selective strength on the export side. And then I think in your prepared commen
componenttext: My question relates to the protein markets right now. Actually, the hog markets have been benefiting quite nicely from a very strong ham export market. It seems like there was selective strength on the export side. And then I think in your prepared comments, Jeff, you talked about very strong exports in the dark turkey export market, the dark parts market, which if you get some good pricing and some good demand in that derivative market, that's really going to help your profitability for Jennie-O. So can you give me a feel of what's going on in these export markets and really the protein markets that -- are these unusual events? Or are these sustainable? And what's driving those things?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, why don't I let Jody start with it and talk about the hog side of the [indiscernible] I could fill in on the turkey market.
componenttext: Well, why don't I let Jody start with it and talk about the hog side of the [indiscernible] I could fill in on the turkey market.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we certainly have seen that exports have been up year-over-year, and I think the USDA's most recent forecast is for a full calendar year to be up about 6%, granted the ban from Russia was just lifted but they do have some restrictions, I believe, on
componenttext: Yes, we certainly have seen that exports have been up year-over-year, and I think the USDA's most recent forecast is for a full calendar year to be up about 6%, granted the ban from Russia was just lifted but they do have some restrictions, I believe, on the amount of tonnage. Really, the drivers have been our neighbors to the north and south, Mexico's strength as well as Canada. How long we expect that to continue, boy, it depends on the economic conditions in those countries, actually, that are going to drive the export as prices continue to stay firm. So I would expect that we'll see exports on the hog side or the meat side or pork side of things to be up in that 5% to 6% for the year.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Eric, on the turkey side, the markets have been quite strong. Based on what we know right now, our anticipation is that they would remain at that level. We've seen quite a recovery on the white meat side of the Turkey business, also in terms of the commod
componenttext: Eric, on the turkey side, the markets have been quite strong. Based on what we know right now, our anticipation is that they would remain at that level. We've seen quite a recovery on the white meat side of the Turkey business, also in terms of the commodity meat markets, and although that has less direct meaning to our result because we don't sell a lot of surplus breast meat, it is supportive of the overall market.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Robert Moskow [Crédit Suisse AG].
componenttext: And the next question comes from Robert Moskow [Crédit Suisse AG].

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you about -- just a broader picture about the impact of higher hog prices on your two businesses. If all of these refrigerated meats and processed meats companies are getting hit by hog prices together, wouldn't it be fair to say that they
componenttext: I wanted to ask you about -- just a broader picture about the impact of higher hog prices on your two businesses. If all of these refrigerated meats and processed meats companies are getting hit by hog prices together, wouldn't it be fair to say that they would all raise prices together because it's just the same impact across everybody?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it certainly is the same impact across everybody, but all businesses have to make independent business decisions. It may be dependent on the strength of their relationship with a given customer or the strength of their brand in a given marketplace.
componenttext: Well, it certainly is the same impact across everybody, but all businesses have to make independent business decisions. It may be dependent on the strength of their relationship with a given customer or the strength of their brand in a given marketplace. But clearly, just as we probably talked a year or two ago about realizing that in the long run the hog production deficit couldn't last -- the hog producers couldn't last forever getting a negative return. Same would be true in terms of cost and pricing in the marketplace that if we attain a new level and it stays there for a while, then in the long run, prices are going to have to migrate up to that new level.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Do you think, stepping back Refrigerated Products, is that kind of the easier part of the business to pass along the higher input cost because they tend to be, I don't want to say, commoditized, but certainly it looks more like a Refrigerated product rath
componenttext: Do you think, stepping back Refrigerated Products, is that kind of the easier part of the business to pass along the higher input cost because they tend to be, I don't want to say, commoditized, but certainly it looks more like a Refrigerated product rather than a packaged product?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Robert, there's a significant portion of the Refrigerated Food sales that, that would definitely be correct for. The fresh pork items clearly trade on a market basis, and ham and bacon sales traditionally in both the retail and Foodservice trade move with
componenttext: Robert, there's a significant portion of the Refrigerated Food sales that, that would definitely be correct for. The fresh pork items clearly trade on a market basis, and ham and bacon sales traditionally in both the retail and Foodservice trade move with markets, and indeed, we have taken pricing on those types of items to reflect what the current market conditions are. The items where you would not see that, where we're holding back and looking at them more as we do the grocery items, would be the pepperoni and the refrigerated entrées and the Natural Choice, those types of items.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: So even Natural Choice, it would be more challenging you think to take prices higher?
componenttext: So even Natural Choice, it would be more challenging you think to take prices higher?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: We just look at it differently. I'm not saying it would be more challenging, but we just look at that as a consumer-packaged item that we don't want to have it just fluctuating all the time based on underlying markets. I mean, Natural Choice, frankly, we
componenttext: We just look at it differently. I'm not saying it would be more challenging, but we just look at that as a consumer-packaged item that we don't want to have it just fluctuating all the time based on underlying markets. I mean, Natural Choice, frankly, we sell roast beef, sliced ham and sliced turkey. So you have all sorts of different inputs within the line, but you want to have a certain target price you're looking for, for those lines. You have promoted prices you're trying to attain, and if we see in the long run that there's just a total difference in the cost that we have to deal with, then we'll have to address it accordingly in pricing, but we just don't do it on as quick a basis.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess if you can kind of get where I'm going here, if there is a negative thesis on Hormel, it is that higher hog prices would impact your earnings growth going forward. I guess what I'm just trying to figure out is: Going into fiscal '11, how big of a
componenttext: I guess if you can kind of get where I'm going here, if there is a negative thesis on Hormel, it is that higher hog prices would impact your earnings growth going forward. I guess what I'm just trying to figure out is: Going into fiscal '11, how big of a negative impact is it really? Is it enough to kind of slow your ability to hit your normal targets? Or is it just something that you can offset through other parts of your portfolio, either because the portfolio is very balanced or because you think that the pricing can eventually cover it?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: We have not completed any sort of budgeting cycle yet for 2011, but I can give you a general sense. We've talked before that one environment for our company that provides some short-term challenges for certain units is when prices go up, costs go up quick
componenttext: We have not completed any sort of budgeting cycle yet for 2011, but I can give you a general sense. We've talked before that one environment for our company that provides some short-term challenges for certain units is when prices go up, costs go up quickly, and we certainly have seen that in the pork area. And so sort of baked into our second half number here is the expectation that it's going to be a more challenging environment for Grocery Products and Refrigerated Foods. We do think some of the other segments can offset that substantially, but that is out there. Our best outlook right now for 2011 would be along the lines of what you're describing, which is I would expect our team to react to the environmental change, and we're either going to have to address pricing if there is a new higher cost level that is going to stay in place. Or if some of those costs recede somewhat, we should be in a position in 2011 to achieve our normal long-term growth objectives.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: So then just a modeling question then. So if we look at fiscal '10 and how it's kind of playing out, the first half of the year, you definitely over-delivered on where you thought you would be, and as we get to the second half of the year, the comparisons
componenttext: So then just a modeling question then. So if we look at fiscal '10 and how it's kind of playing out, the first half of the year, you definitely over-delivered on where you thought you would be, and as we get to the second half of the year, the comparisons are tougher. Operating profit growth was very big in the second half of fiscal '09, so it will be a comparison issue and maybe a little bit of a challenging environment because of the higher hog prices. It's kind of like a tale of two halves for fiscal '10.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's fair. But again, we try to run the business on the basis of the full year, and that was part of why we moved to annualized guidance. By moving up our guidance range now -- it's the second time we've done it this year -- the midpoint of that
componenttext: I think that's fair. But again, we try to run the business on the basis of the full year, and that was part of why we moved to annualized guidance. By moving up our guidance range now -- it's the second time we've done it this year -- the midpoint of that range would be a solid 10% increase on an earnings-per-share basis over last year's results and a better increase than that on an operating profit basis because you want to wash out the rabbi trust effects. So we're going to look at the year as, if we can deliver the second half the way we’ve described it as being, a very successful year and one we can build on going forward.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Ann Gurkin [Davenport & Company].
componenttext: And the next question comes from Ann Gurkin [Davenport & Company].

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: You all have accumulated a nice amount of cash on your balance sheet. Just wondering if you could review your priorities of cash again.
componenttext: You all have accumulated a nice amount of cash on your balance sheet. Just wondering if you could review your priorities of cash again.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Jody, would you like to address that one?
componenttext: Jody, would you like to address that one?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Ann, I'm afraid they haven't changed since last time, but certainly, as Jeff indicated before, we continue to look at opportunities to invest strategically, either internally. Our CapEx spending has been lower, and I guided the full year a little bit lowe
componenttext: Ann, I'm afraid they haven't changed since last time, but certainly, as Jeff indicated before, we continue to look at opportunities to invest strategically, either internally. Our CapEx spending has been lower, and I guided the full year a little bit lower because while we've got great projects in the pipeline, it seems to be that we're taking a little longer than I originally anticipated in getting some of those things done and equipment ordered and what-not. So CapEx should be coming back online and getting back to more normalized levels in the back half of the year. So we look at acquisitions, investing in our own business. Certainly, we're committed to our dividends to our shareholders and share repurchase as well. So those seem to be the key.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Mike Hamilton [RBC Capital Markets].
componenttext: And the next question comes from Mike Hamilton [RBC Capital Markets].

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: One question that was a few parts, Jeff. It's been a while since I've heard you discuss the dynamics of your hog contract, and I'm just wondering, given the volatility of what we've been through, kind of from 30,000 feet if you could assess what you've ac
componenttext: One question that was a few parts, Jeff. It's been a while since I've heard you discuss the dynamics of your hog contract, and I'm just wondering, given the volatility of what we've been through, kind of from 30,000 feet if you could assess what you've accomplished, what you're seeing out there -- if you think you're taking market share, if this environment is giving an opportunity to continue to upgrade the quality of your producers in terms of their financial strength and capabilities. Just kind of the picture, as you see it, of the progress you've made there.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: If it's okay, I'll have Jody proceed with that question.
componenttext: If it's okay, I'll have Jody proceed with that question.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Our hog contracts generally are based on markets, so it's usually a spread to the Western Cornbelt since that's where most of our hogs are sourced. So we really do kind of follow the market. We have been fortunate that the producers we've aligned ourselve
componenttext: Our hog contracts generally are based on markets, so it's usually a spread to the Western Cornbelt since that's where most of our hogs are sourced. So we really do kind of follow the market. We have been fortunate that the producers we've aligned ourselves with have had a lot of financial strength. Some of the smaller operators have fallen on the wayside when they've got in over their heads and were losing money, but generally our producers have been stronger. And we continue to work with other producers that maybe are unhappy with their current packer that they're dealing with and have some opportunities there, so we feel very comfortable about the supply of hogs for the future for Hormel, and these are generally long-term contracts, five to 10 years.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Diane Geissler [Credit Agricole Securities].
componenttext: And the next question comes from Diane Geissler [Credit Agricole Securities].

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Jody, I think you said you repurchased 330,000 shares and you had a little bit over 300,000 left on your share buyback. Is that correct?
componenttext: Jody, I think you said you repurchased 330,000 shares and you had a little bit over 300,000 left on your share buyback. Is that correct?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me dig out the exact number for you since I..
componenttext: Yes, let me dig out the exact number for you since I..

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe while you're looking for that, can you tell me when does the board reconsider, because you’re almost out on your share authorization? So is that something the board takes up on a quarterly basis? Or how does that go?
componenttext: Maybe while you're looking for that, can you tell me when does the board reconsider, because you’re almost out on your share authorization? So is that something the board takes up on a quarterly basis? Or how does that go?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: The last time we had an authorization, I think it was in 2003 that it was implemented, so obviously, we've been given a long term for it. There's 367,000 shares that were left at the end of the second quarter. I certainly would recommend to the board that
componenttext: The last time we had an authorization, I think it was in 2003 that it was implemented, so obviously, we've been given a long term for it. There's 367,000 shares that were left at the end of the second quarter. I certainly would recommend to the board that we do an additional authorization, but that's obviously something that the board would decide, and I don't think there's any specific timing to that to answer your question.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And we have a follow-up question from Christina McGlone [Deutsche Bank AG].
componenttext: And we have a follow-up question from Christina McGlone [Deutsche Bank AG].

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Jody, you said CapEx guidance was $105 million to $115 million. Is that down? I thought it more in the $130 million to $140 million range before. Is it...
componenttext: Jody, you said CapEx guidance was $105 million to $115 million. Is that down? I thought it more in the $130 million to $140 million range before. Is it...

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry to interrupt you; did you have more to the question?
componenttext: I'm sorry to interrupt you; did you have more to the question?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: No. Am I right? And if that's true, why is it down?
componenttext: No. Am I right? And if that's true, why is it down?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: As I'd indicated in an answer to Ann earlier was we have projects in the pipeline for CapEx. It's not for lack of wanting to do things. They just seem to be taking longer than I originally anticipated in my guidance, so I did pull it down for the full yea
componenttext: As I'd indicated in an answer to Ann earlier was we have projects in the pipeline for CapEx. It's not for lack of wanting to do things. They just seem to be taking longer than I originally anticipated in my guidance, so I did pull it down for the full year. I think it's being conservative. We might go over that, but I was trying to give you a real picture of where I felt our CapEx spending would be. The bute [ph] plant is basically up and going. Obviously, we're adding some additional production capabilities into there. That should get in this year. I know Jennie-O's got some specific projects that they're working on, but they don't seem to be happening as fast as I thought they would.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And we have another follow-up question from Akshay Jagdale [KeyBanc Capital Markets].
componenttext: And we have another follow-up question from Akshay Jagdale [KeyBanc Capital Markets].

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Just one comment and then I wanted to get your reaction, Jeff or Jody. Most of your protein competitors -- publicly traded ones who are more, I would say, on the non-value-added side -- had said that we are tight protein right now, especially beef and por
componenttext: Just one comment and then I wanted to get your reaction, Jeff or Jody. Most of your protein competitors -- publicly traded ones who are more, I would say, on the non-value-added side -- had said that we are tight protein right now, especially beef and pork and chicken may be changing, and in that environment some of the publicly traded ones have actually increased their normalized margin ranges for pork margins, et cetera. Do you agree that we are in a "tight protein"? And if that's the case, doesn't that bode well for pricing in Grocery Products as you look at it over the next six months or so?

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Akshay, I would agree that protein is certainly significantly tighter than it was a year ago or two years ago. The pricing equation has other elements to it. I mean, you have to look at other feature alternatives that the retailers have. We certainly have
componenttext: Akshay, I would agree that protein is certainly significantly tighter than it was a year ago or two years ago. The pricing equation has other elements to it. I mean, you have to look at other feature alternatives that the retailers have. We certainly have to be mindful of a consumer that in many cases is having a constrained budget and is looking for as good a value as possible on items, and so we have to balance what the needs would be in terms of pricing to cover down our costs and what the market will bear in terms of what our consumers are looking to pay.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We do not appear to have any further questions. Please continue with any points you wish to raise.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We do not appear to have any further questions. Please continue with any points you wish to raise.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you everybody for your participation today. I will get back to the sell-side analysts to cover us with some contact information and where I'll be later this week. I'm going to be tied up in a conference today, but I will give you some contact inform
componenttext: Thank you everybody for your participation today. I will get back to the sell-side analysts to cover us with some contact information and where I'll be later this week. I'm going to be tied up in a conference today, but I will give you some contact information so we can talk tomorrow, if not later today. Thank you very much. Have a great day, everyone. Goodbye.

headline: Hormel Foods Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May-19-2010

componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes the Hormel Foods Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Thank you for your participation, and you may now disconnect.
